comment_0:
Hey guys, awesome interpretations so far.  Again this is everyone's THOUGHTS, so if I seem to dis anyone or anything by what I say, nothin bad intended.  I think it's great seein what other people think.  Anyway, on to the interpretation.
To begin with, I wanna clear up an earlier post.  Colsy said the title was pronounced "Lateral-Us" (A mistake i made too for a long time) but it's really pronounced "Ladder-alice" (say it and it makes sense, i found this in the FAQ from toolshed.net). Instead of "Side of Us", i think the song deals with lateral parts (the bigger picture, as maynard put it).  Anyway, it deals with the ability to have a physical life, as well as a spiritual one (In whatever god you chose to believe in).
"Black then white are all i see in my infancy" (at birth and early on you only see what's plain to the human eye, the physical side of life)
"Red and yellow came to be, reaching out for me" (how spiritual feelings creep up after sometime, and almost seem to make you realize a new side of life)

To keep from breaking down every line in the song (like i did on "the grudge") i'll just say that the next section deals with testing spiritual life (pushin that envelope, watching it bend, almost to see how far it will go). spiritual life takes you 'beyond the lines of reason'. 

Yet he retracts these statements by talking about "OVER thinking, and OVER analyzing" (saying that there is a balance in spirit and body, don't push either ot the extreme, because you'll become separate humans, leading a LATERAL life)
Then he speaks about reaching out to embrace the random.... possibly spiritual meaning saying that he holds on to a belief hoping that he can eventually find truth in it.
The next part seems to be my strongest point of backing.  he speaks about how he has the desire to do all of these wonderful (spiritual and physical) things, and he sums it all up by saying 
"swing on the spiral of our divinity and still be a human" (think about it... the lateral lives of body and spirit NEVER have to each other, they can stay completely separate, but he longs to bring them together, to SPIRAL them, and make such a connection to feel DIVINE but remain a HUMAN.)

Next he backs my statement again.  He speaks of 'keeping his feet on the ground', yet he also talks about an enlightenment of somekind 'opening wide to suck it in and feeling it move across his skin'.
He wants that connection of body and spirit, as everyone does.  He'll continue to connect the 2 to push the boundaries and enlighten himself
"Spiral out, keep going...."

And interpretation is now done, thanks for botherin to read this terribly long post (as are all of mine, sorry bout that).  Anyway, continue writin posts, i love to read em, and again this is only my opinion.  Later...
comment_1:
This is one of the most brilliant songs ever written.  Like a complex novel, it operates on many levels, but the central theme of the song is evolution, both personal and on the grand scale.  First we'll examine the music itself.  Note that in the beginning the background beats/rhythms sound almost like a bubbling swamp, which is the source of life.  As the song progresses, those rhythms become more tribal, then more mechanical, till near the end we hear what sounds like robots in a factory.  Thus, the music is about the evolution of the human species to the point where we are either replaced by machines or become machines ourselves.  

Now, the lyrics reinforce this theme on a few ways.  The song starts out: "Black then white are all I see in my infancy, red and yellow then came to be reaching out to me, let's me see."  On a very literal level this is exactly how vision evolves in each human.  Babies see in black and white, with their ability to distinguish colors arising as they age.  But this is also true of the human species in a philosophical and spiritual sense.  Edward O. Wilson has written about how the most primitive tribes have words only for black and white; the next most advanced tribes have words for red and yellow, on up to the point where we recognize there is a near infinite color spectrum, which the most advanced cultures recognize.  Thus, the most morally developed beings recognize that issues can never be easily divided into black and white; that's much too simplistic.  There are, of course, people who still see moral issues in black and white, but they are throwbacks to our primitive heritage.  So as technology advances, if we do not evolve morally too, we lose our connection to nature more and more and become little more than machines.  Computers too view things in simplistic black and white terms (or bits and bytes if you prefer).  

Thus, in that context the song is about personal growth--spiritually, morally, and philosophically speaking.  when Maynard sings about pushing the envelope, he is saying that he is attempting to push beyond the 2-dimensional mores and prudish religious nonsense that still holds us back as a culture.  True spiritual growth cannot come from without; it must come from within, and no one else can define what is right or wrong for you.  In that sense this sing is kind of a companion piece to Hermann Hesse's novel 'Demian.'  

As the song approaches its denouement, Maynard approaches something on the order of mystical ecstasy and again the music reinforces the lyrics.  Note how the pitch of Maynard's voice, moving up and down rhythmically, compliments the "spiral out" he's singing about.  He leaves the rest ambiguous.  What lies beyond the simplistic black & white world we live in?  Who knows?  But the point is, we must push ahead anyway, no matter what, because the alternative is that we're no better than the machines we build to labor for us.  We MUST stop looking at the world as if it can be divided into easy categories.  The truth is never that simple.  We may not like what we find as we move on; nevertheless, we advance or we die, spiritually speaking.

Black, white, red and green are the colours given by Buddhists for the 4 directions of their spiritual world. Black and white represent our realm, basically good vs evil, green and yellow are the higher and lower realms, gods vs demons (give them what names you will).

red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me. 
lets me see."
Anyone else notice that the colors mentioned are the traditional "skin tones?"  What does that have to do with it?  I'm not sure.

"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine 
drawn beyond the lines of reason. 
Push the envelope. Watch it bend."
In other words, open your eyes to other possibilities... what you don't see.  What you can't see.

Don't think... feel.  Don't stay within the boundaries of society.  This song means a LOT to me... so much that I can't put it into words.

"Feed my will to feel this moment urging me to cross the line.

comment_5:
This song is a description of a mystical experience.

"Black then white are all I see in my infancy.
Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me.
Lets me see."
As infants, we are only capable of seeing black and white before we become capable of seeing color. Likewise, as we mature spiritually we become capable of perceiving different aspects of reality that were previously completely unknown and unimaginable to us. A mystical experience is so alien to the everyday experiences of most people that describing it analogous to describing color to a colorblind person. Even if they can intellectually understand it, they can never truly "know" color without direct experience. Neither can anyone truly "know" divinity with a mere intellectual understanding of it.

"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
Drawn beyond the lines of reason.
Push the envelope. Watch it bend."
In esoteric traditions "As above, so below" is an extremely famous phrase referring to the concept that the microcosm of the human is a representation of the macrocosm of the universe and vice versa; therefore through understanding one you understand the other. This is not a concept that can be rationally understood, hence it is "drawn beyond the lines of reason." It can only be accurately perceived when the rational mind is pushed to its breaking point, when it can be transcended.

"Over thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind.
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must
Feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines."
The rational mind can only exist in a dualistic world, i.e. a world where subject and object, or the knower and the known, are separated. This duality is an illusion that is fooling the narrator, who must strengthen his will to see through the illusion.

"Feed my will to feel this moment urging me to cross the line.
Reaching out to embrace the random.
Reaching out to embrace whatever may come."
It takes a tremendous amount of willpower to cross the line from duality to unity. The individual never really knows what to expect when their ego becomes purified and they can perceive the infinite.

"I embrace my desire to
Feel the rhythm, to feel connected
Enough to step aside and weep like a widow
To feel inspired, to fathom the power,
To witness the beauty, to bathe in the fountain,
To swing on the spiral
Of our divinity and still be a human."
This is the desire for liberation from the chains of worldly existence, or to experience the Mystical unity of the universe. The joy of this unity is enough to make the narrator cry. "The power," "the beauty," "the fountain," and "the spiral" are descriptions of divinity. "The fountain" probably refers to the fountain of life, while spirals are filled with esoteric significance relating to the golden ratio and DNA.

"With my feet upon the ground I lose myself
Between the sounds and open wide to suck it in,
I feel it move across my skin.
I'm reaching up and reaching out,
I'm reaching for the random or what ever will bewilder me.
And following our will and wind we may just go where no one's been.
We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been."
After this mystical experience, the narrator's desire to reach even further into to fabric of reality is intensified and they assert their intention to continue their spiritual evolution to its conclusion.

comment_8:
I think this song is about how if you think too much you lose touch with your intuition, emotional and spiritual side. This song has helped me alot. I wrote an essay about how it compares to the book "The Master and His Emissary", which is about how in Western society we overuse the right hemisphere of our brains (the logical side) at the expense of our left hemisphere (the emotional and spiritual side). Here's my interpretation.

"Black then white are all I see in my infancy": I saw things in a simple, inaccurate way, thanks partly to my society favouring the use of the right hemisphere of the brain.
"Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me, lets me see": I began to see subtlety and complexity in life after I began to use my left hemisphere more.

"As below so above and beyond I Imagine": a reference the Hermetic philosophy, patterns we notice on Earth can be extrapolated to apply to higher dimensions
"Drawn beyond the lines of reason ...": Rational thinking has its own limits, for example logic can't justify the use of logic or give you a purpose for living. Life with only logic is empty, cold and meaningless.

"Over thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind": Over use of the right hemisphere of the brain weakens your connection to the left hemisphere.
"Withering my intuition": If you can't use your left hemisphere then you don't have access to intuition and creativity.
"And I must feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines": Will power probably comes from the left hemisphere, it is the "Master" and the right hemisphere is its "Emissary" because only the left hemisphere can answer the question "Why?", to the right hemisphere everything is just a task to complete.

"There is so much more, and beckons me to look through to these infinite possibilities": There's alot of life experience I'm missing out on by not using my left hemisphere enough.

"Feed my will to feel this moment urging me to cross the line.": Staying in the same old thinking patterns isn't going to lead me to new experiences.
"Reaching out to embrace the random. Reaching out to embrace whatever may come.": Emotions, intuition and new experiences are random, I have to be okay with that if I want to live life to the fullest.

And the rest of the song is how he feels once he has embraced his left hemisphere, his life feels more meaningful and less monotonous.
comment_9:
On the surface Lateralus is an amazing song in it's own right. The concept of Lateral-us is for an individual to view the themselves laterally - to view the world from outside one's own existence and see the bigger picture. The song uses the concept to "spiral out", to encourage the listener to evolve - to be more humane.

Below the surface is a surprising amount of metaphors and concepts adding much deeper meaning. These include the use of the Fibonacci sequence and references to alchemy as summarised below:

1. The fibonacci sequence
 - Lyrics are introduced at 1.61... minutes - the golden/divine ration used by part of the Fibonacci sequence and divine proportions.
 - The time signatures of the song switch between 9/8, 8/8 and 7/8 - 987 being the 16th step of the Fibonacci sequences.
 - The chorus is sung in the pattern of the Fibonacci squence (i.e. 1-1-2-3-5-8-13 and back), noting at times steps are missed - implying some thing is missing.

2. Alchemy (Jung)
The "Magnum Opus" is the alchemy process for creating the philospher's stone, a substance that can turn lead into gold (ref. to The Grudge). This required both chemical and spiritual aspects. Carl Jung drew on some of these ideas to explain the concept of the individuation process. The colours used in the chorus draw on following Jung concepts:
 - Nigredo (black) - Encoutering the unconcious mind
 - Albedo (white) - Purification of the unconcious thoughts
 - Critrinitas (yellow) - Confronting the Wise old man archetype.
 - Rubedo (red) - Discovering the true self

When reviewing these details against the lyrics song adds much more meaning. There is not one meaning to this song, the abstract lyrics will have a personal meaning to each individual. This song simply put is encouraging the listener to strive towards being to being a better person.

comment_13:
Overall, anyone who is experienced in sheet music, time signatures, and math. Should realize that the time signatures go through shifts like so. 9/8,8/8,7/8 which if you read the top numbers it would read 987 which coincidentally is the 16th number in a pattern of numbers called the Fibonacci code. But that isn't the only reference to this code, the first verse will have a portion of the Fibonacci code (112358) which is quite convenient. That's not what the song means but I thought it was quite creative of Maynard and tool to decide to incorporate this sequence in their song. 
For those curious the Fibonacci Code is an infinite sequence in which every number is equal to the sum of the two digits before it. For example, 1 1 is equal to 2 so the first three digits are 112 followed by 3. This code is related to Phi or the Golden ratio. And the mathematical spiral which can be laid over a number of things to find an infinite solutions. 
This same concept was also used in Television, art, movies, architecture, etc. I.e. Criminal minds "Mastermind" in which the killer uses phi and the Fibonacci code to hide his victims.

comment_15:
A lot of good points have been made thus far, but thereâs a few things I want to touch on.  Many people interpret Maynard based on writings he has recommended.  While I havenât read many of his selected works, I feel his lyrics can be interpreted without a great deal of side researchâparticularly in Lateralus.  So Iâll continue into the songâ¦
We are born into the world with no real sense of the world.  We start seeing things in black and white, good and bad, 1 or 0.  But as we become more aware of ourselves and the world around us, we see these distinct lines blur, new colors, new concepts, are all out there, waiting to be understood, and adapted into our own lives.  This is an eternal concept, starting ages ago for our ancestors, and will be for ages.  We are here to stretch our own minds.

âOver thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind.â  
This is a key theme in the song.  It can be interpreted many ways.  I fist saw it as stating that over thinking, over analyzing is what differentiates the body from the mind.  The eye is not aware it is an eye, but the brain is.  Thatâs the difference.  Thus, we are different from every other species of being we know of, in that we are aware, evolve, and grow.
But thatâs not the only way to interpret it.   Looking at further lines, leads me to believe that he is saying that over-thinking, over-analyzing is what creates a void between thought and action.  Generally more contemplative people have a tendency to be more timid, a sociological concept that many may be familiar with.  Thus, we must somehow seek the inspiration to act on our ideas.  Rather than the usual black and white conversation, we must seek the strength to be open and honest about our ideas, our opinions, to leave ourselves vulnerable.

He continues to stress the need for inspiration.  Here it seems like Maynard is writing in retrospectionâreliving the agonies he must have had before he began writing, and exposing his ideas to the public.  To reach out and be new, be bold, be daring.  Bewilderment is a sense of detachment from explanation, to have something new to contemplateâsomething new to consider.

He then reverts out of retrospection.  I feel the desire toâ¦ followed by imagery that is incredibly poetic, and powerful, from sadness to elation.  Maynard then states, âto swing on the spiral of our divinity, and still be a human.â  I still donât know if I understand this lineâbut it is essential.  From some reflection, he is essentially saying that we should continue to evolve, change, think, act, live, and love, to our fullestâbecome Godlike, or Christ-like if that image is clearer.  Maynard is emphasizing this urge throughout the song, because it is difficult.  So many things in society are constructed to block us from this goal.  We want to be open, honest, and loving, but in a society filled with cynicism and hate, we need courage and desire to be the best people we can be.

âWith my feet upon the ground I lose myself between the soundsâ¦â  Maynard states that he is just as much a part of Human kind as anyone else.  He is open to the world around him, and welcomes everything it has to offer, good or bad.  Maynard claims he is living by example, and compels us all to do the same.  Following our drives may just take humanity where no one has been.  After all, Maynard is not singing to Baby Boomers, or Soccer Moms, he is singing to societies youth.  By living our lives, we set examples for others, and future generations, so by living a life of better humanity, we can improve society for later generations.

Thatâs all I can say for Lateralus now.  By walking through that song again I realized myself some new things in the song.  I think there is so much meaning in Lateralus that it will never be simply explained, I think it is designed for contemplation.

comment_22:
hey there toolarmy. i love this song. there is so much to it, a lot of which has already been picked up, so i'll just give you some random thoughts: all the words inside quotation marks are tool lyrics. most of them are from this song, some are not.

*this song was originally going to be called 987. this is a reference to certain mathematical phenomena that occurs in nature, such as the fibonaci series and the golden ratio, which occurs in spirals, from fern fronds to the spiral form of some galaxies (including our one, the milky way). this theme is also reflected technically in the music, the latter half of the song being played in repeating 9,8,7 time signatures, (if you are a guitar freak and that means anything to you). so what, you ask. well, if you listen to the lyrics of other songs on this album a recurring theme emerges of being 'one' with nature, by letting go of your 'grudges' and ego, by 'rediscovering communication', by 'embracing this holy reality' etc. 

*physiologically, the first colours infants are able to distinguish is black and white, then as the brain develops its visual processes, other colours, (e.g. red and yellow) -yes, and in that order, are able to be perceived. that's nice. what's it mean? my interpretation - we are born without judgements, grudges, ego - these are things that we aquire, and it is how we deal with this that will either lead to it destroying you i.e. it will 'consume you till you let it go' like on The Grudge or it 'lets me see'. for a great analysis of what these colours mean, see 'astro' and his/her comments above, which i fully agree with.

*what about the 'drawing way outside the lines', 'reaching out to embrace the random' and the 'infinite possibilities' lyrics? again, tool go mathematical. if you think this is all a bit far fetched, keep in mind that danny carey (drummer) is a huge fan of this kind of stuff. anyway, these lyrics can be tied into a thing called Chaos Theory. basically, when scientists started analyzing atoms and molecules right down to their very smallest sub-particles, they discovered that they don't conform to ordered laws, but were in fact, totally random. an offshoot of this Chaos theory is the idea of Fractals, which i won't go into here, you can look it up yourselves but it has to do with 'lines' - see the connection? if not, read the lyrics. i.e. there is no stable, comfortable, rational order in this world, but we must not be afraid of it, but 'embrace the random.' still reaching way out into left field? well have a look at the end of the 'parabola' music video. the human being sprouts all sorts of lines from his body which merges with all these other lines, so you can no longer tell where the human ends and the universe begins.

*by the way, the fractal thing i mentioned above, they 'bend' remind you of anything? 'push the envelope, watch it bend'

*for the 'over-thinking, over-analyzing' lines, see the comments of 'hoomanhah' above,who has some great ideas.

*the 'I embrace my Desire to...Feel the rhythm, to Feel connected Enough to step aside and Weep like a widow...' is another great moment in this song. truly attentive tool fans will have noticed that this bit is an answer to the problem posed in the song 'H' on the Aenima album. there, the person was 'too connected to slip away, fade away...' but here, due to all the above factors, he is now 'connected enough to step aside' i.e. he (or she) has reached another level of awareness, which lets them step aside from damaging relationships, which was what H was all about.

*my favourit line - 'to swing on the spiral of our divinity, and still be a human' - i could write a whole book just on these 13 words, but relax, i won't. in brief - by opening ourselves to the (Chaotic) world around us, by being aware enough to glimpse these 'infinite possibilities' we realize that there is no one controlling god - we are all gods, linked together. am i reading too much into it? well just look at the transparent liner notes for the album. on the last page, if you look carefully, you will see the word 'god' written into the persons brain. i.e. we are our own gods, we determine our (and our surrounding peoples/loved ones') fate. we can swing on the spiral of our divinity, a line which refers to the spirals i talked about earlier, i.e. here it specifically refers to the cosmos/galaxy, i.e. we can be one with ALL of our surroundings if we are open to them, but 'still be a human' and to be human is to 'embrace my desire' to 'feel' to 'weep' to 'fathom' to 'witness' to 'open wide' and 'embrace the random' not just to over-think and over-analyze, and if we gods can do that, then 'we'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no-ones been'.

-thank you for taking the time to read this, i welcome any thoughts or opinions. stay human.

One of my friends (A huge fan of the band) told me this song is actually about a mathematical theory (Not Pi, a different one.) He said it's basically an endless spiral of numbers, and that is what this theory says makes up our psychical being. Hence, the song might be about following the lines of our own existence to wherever they may lead us. Basically dissecting our lives to discover what exactly 'humans' really are.

I'm not sure if he's right, but it sounds pretty legit to me.

I originally interpreted it to be that he's talking about ignoring society's set rules and set thoughts to discover the meaning behind emotion. 'Going where no one's been' could be describing learning the secrets of life and existence. What we know to be real is only real because we are taught that it is. For instance, if someone is born without the ability to see the lines, any set boundaries of sight at all, would they see in a giant mess of color because it all runs together, or would it all just be almost inconceivably blurry? What we see is what we are taught. To me this song symbolizes breaking from what we are taught to glean understanding of existence on our own.

comment_30:
Black then white are all I see in my infancy.
Red and yellow then came to be, 
reaching out to me, lets me see.  --  In the beginning of a human life, the child is unaware of its own existence, past, future of death. The baby exists in 'black and white', it is what it is. At about aged 4 - 6 the child gradually begins to become aware of itself as being a form, and begins the (unnecessary) process of layering itself up with ideas, concepts, beliefs and self-image, hence the 'red and yellow'. When the narrator says 'lets me see' I interpret this as him seeing with his eyes in order to interpret the external as reality, rather than the internal 'true' reality.

As below so above and beyond I imagine,
drawn beyond the lines of reason.
Push the envelope. Watch it bend.  --  The narrator seems to be conveying the common misconception that what is real on Earth must therefore apply also to what we cannot see 'above and beyond', drawn beyond the lines of reason, of what we can understand using reason and logic. The last line may refer to cause and effect.

Over thinking, over analyzing,
separates the body from the mind.
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must
feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines.  --  The 'existence' within all of us doesn't require thought or analysis to be present. Thought and analysis take over intuition. We spend too much time and effort in thinking. Thought is simply a remembered past or an imagined future, hence the only true reality is this second, now. In over thinking and analysing we often miss what is right in front of us, so the narrator realises he has to will himself to let his 'moment' (the present) take him where it goes, without the distraction of thought.

Feed my will to feel this moment, urging me to cross the line.
Reaching out to embrace the random. 
Reaching out to embrace whatever may come.  --  Again, this refers to the narrator's attempts to become enlightened and to 'stay present' in the moment. Embracing the random and embracing whatever may come is the way in which to remain present, because what IS, simply IS.

I embrace my desire to...
I embrace my desire to...
feel the rhythm, 
to feel connected enough to step aside and weep like a widow,
to feel inspired,
to fathom the power, 
to witness the beauty, 
to bathe in the fountain, 
to swing on the spiral,
to swing on the spiral,
to swing on the spiral of our divinity and still be a human.  --  The lines in this verse all seem to refer to the feelings and experiences of becoming enlightened - 'feeling' the rhythm, feeling connected enough to allow feelings to 'be', witnessing true beauty is only possible when one has become enlightened. 'Swing on the spiral' is an interesting lyric alone as it may refer to numerous things. My thought is that a spiral could represent physical phenomena such as DNA and galaxies, or it could represent a singular path that we all must travel - one that has a beginning without, and ends at a point within.

With my feet upon the ground,
I lose myself between the sounds and open wide to suck it in. 
I feel it move across my skin. 
I'm reaching up and reaching out. 
I'm reaching for the random or whatever will bewilder me,
whatever will bewilder me.  --  Feet upon the ground possibly means that the narrator is aware that he is still human and that he still exists as a physical form, however he is able to 'lose himself' to the moment of simply 'being'. Some people who have experienced enlightenment or moments of enlightened awareness describe the feeling of tingling across the body, as though energy has permeated the physical body. Reaching up and reaching out could mean that the narrator is experiencing a spiritual transformation and is able to 'reach out' and understand more to his existence.

The IRONY of these lyrics is that providing an explanation and offering some resources (in interviews, articles, album materials) to help people access good materials on spiritual alchemy would be such a lovely egoless thing to do--as opposed to leaving it shrouded in mystery.  Those who are not interested won't "seek" or find it important.   If MJK ever goes to that next step- to serve his listeners both art to be inspired by as well as access to the resources he knows damn well can transform a person --I'll be jumping up and down.  In the meantime - I'll write this and maybe some Tool fan who is "ready" will dive into the practice of getting your immortal groove on. 

"Alchemy 1A": a lot of these lyrics were copied straight from old hermetic-alchemy texts.  The whole color changing references symbolize a person's gradual (purification etc) and transmutation of the self-spirit.  You can google it and read it for yourself (keep in mind older terms like "rubedo" are used in place of the word "red."  

As far as the sucking in air and feeling it across the skin etc. --perhaps he's making reference to one of the very first exercises or rituals performed by kaballists, alchemists etc. called the "lesser ritual of the pentagram."  You can watch people perform it on Youtube.  If a person can get past "feeling like a weirdo" (ego) and really get into it, really practice it- an attitude of  "infinite possibilities" really begins to manifest and once a person starts to notice the interconnectedness of generating sound and new energies to what happens in your life - well, its pretty much a guarantee that you're gonna "go" somewhere unchartered.  Mysterious truths WILL be laid out before you.  No drugs required.

I'm no Tool expert, but I'm familiar with a lot of occult materials and these lyrics are common utterances amongst practitioners. 

And the Grudge lyrics - if a person can't get past the self-destructive force of uncontrolled grudges -they will never be able to manipulate energy successfully.  But if they can get all fired up and DIRECT that energy toward some wound or weakness that in turn transforms something permanently within themselves--they permanently operate from a higher vibration in that area they were battling--they are making progress on a timeless soul level.   Perhaps you don't believe in reincarnation, but that's the whole point of working on transmutation from a deeper perspective than mere psychotherapy -its about the LONG long, long run.   

A great, non-threatening place to start understanding some of the hidden knowledge Maynard has accessed is to read the book "The Kybalion" by three initiates.  You can download it for free on the Internet or if you get the free Kindle app-you can get a free copy of it that way too. 

Peace.
comment_34:
The song is about lateral thinking, hence the name "lateralus" (alternatively it could be a reference to the lateralization of the brain, and "thinking with the right brain" would be lateral thinking). Lateral problem solving is coming up with creative, indirect solutions, not just following a formula tackling obvious factors and logically advancing from there, and it's essential that multiple solutions are viable. 

"Black then white are all I see in my infancy.
Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me."

When you were young you thought in black and white, only seeing one solution, but latter you realize there is infinite possibilities, and the ideal compels you. You find the need to be creative. 

"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
Drawn beyond the lines of reason.
Push the envelope. Watch it bend."

More being imaginative and pushing beyond the usual bounds governed by traditional rational thinking. It's pretty straight forward.

"Over thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind.
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must
Feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines."

I think the lateralization of the hemispheres approach works better for the chorus. Interpreting it that way would essentially be saying overusing the left brain (over thinking, over analyzing) causes the right brain to atrophize (Withering my intuition) which weakens the complete mind (separates the body from the mind) and the cure is lateral thinking (I must
Feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines)

The next verse is pretty much the same as the first one, pretty straightforward. 

"Feed my will to feel this moment urging me to cross the line.
Reaching out to embrace the random.
Reaching out to embrace whatever may come."
More about the innate need to be creative, and not just follow already established patterns (reaching out to embrace the random).

"I embrace my desire to
Feel the rhythm, to feel connected"
Reference to music. Rhythm is processed by the right hemisphere.
"Enough to step aside and weep like a widow
To feel inspired, to fathom the power,
To witness the beauty, to bathe in the fountain,"
Talking about the potential from seeing the rest of the picture instead of just the black and white.
"To swing on the spiral
Of our divinity and still be a human."
Reference to the Fibonacci sequence, which is a theme in the song. Not exactly sure how it connects to the rest of the lyrics except for being a metaphor for the whole experience instead of just traditional rational thinking.   

"With my feet upon the ground I lose myself
Between the sounds and open wide to suck it in,
I feel it move across my skin.
I'm reaching up and reaching out,
I'm reaching for the random or what ever will bewilder me.
And following our will and wind we may just go where no one's been.
We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been.

Spiral out. Keep going, going"

Just a continuation of the spiral metaphor.
comment_35:
I can't help but think of astral projection throughout the entire song. 

"Black then white are all I see in my infancy.
Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me.
Lets me see."

When beginning the process of putting yourself into a relaxed state, you close your eyes and initially all you see is black. Then, as many astral projection guides suggest, you see a white light envelop you. I believe "red and yellow" then refers to the colors you start seeing through your third eye that seem to be "reaching out" towards you and creating images in your mind ("lets me see").

"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
Drawn beyond the lines of reason.
Push the envelope. Watch it bend."

There are different planes of existence, the one we reside in is "below" the astral plane. Actually, there is a whole plane in between the one we are in and the astral, so it is "above and beyond". These planes can't be factually or scientifically explained, it's more of a faith. Therefore, "drawn beyond the lines of reason". Many astral projectors experience a sort of wall when making that last push from our world to the next ("push the envelope, watch it bend).

"Over thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind.
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must
Feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines."

A huge obstacle in any intentional OOBE is "over thinking, over analyzing". The importance of remaining calm is largely stressed, when you think too much about it or get excited, it halts your progress making it impossible. The rest is about needing to get rid of human intuition because it's getting in the way of a spiritual adventure. His will to embrace the experience has to overcome the comfort of reasonable reality. 


"...there is so much more
And beckons me to look through to these infinite possibilities."

It is said you can do, go, and see anything you want in the astral plane; "Infinite possibilities"!


"Feed my will to feel this moment urging me to cross the line.
Reaching out to embrace the random.
Reaching out to embrace whatever may come."

Again, referring to that wall. Needing will power to stay focused on pushing through the wall, or line to the other side. It is accompanied by a sensation of "reaching out" or floating up. 

"I embrace my desire to
Feel the rhythm, to feel connected
Enough to step aside and weep like a widow
To feel inspired, to fathom the power,
To witness the beauty, to bathe in the fountain,
To swing on the spiral"

There is a rhythm during the experience, some feel a sensation of spinning or rocking back and forth. It is said that there is a tether, a silver 'rope' that connects you from your astral self to your human body. (feel connected) Going through the experience creates a very vulnerable feeling throughout your being, some have reported crying or intense fear after attempts. The spiral is something I've seen every single time I attempt OOBE's. I feel like the spiral is sucking me in and I'm swaying in rhythm with it.

"Of our divinity and still be a human.With my feet upon the ground I lose myself
Between the sounds and open wide to suck it in,
I feel it move across my skin.
I'm reaching up and reaching out,
I'm reaching for the random or what ever will bewilder me."

The higher planes of existence are considered to be divine, the highest plane being one of 'angels'. A common experience has been not only the sensation, but the visualization of standing up on oneself (with my feet upon the ground) as if it's solid ground. During the ripping down of the wall to the other side, you often hear many sounds. I have heard pretty frightening voices, and sounds that sound like sound. Lol makes sense right? The best I can explain it is like a sonic wave. "Feel it move across my skin" you get immense physical sensations of warmth and tingling throughout your body that starts from your extremities and moves uniformly. "Reaching out and reaching up", you're trying and trying to push through, move up and out. Like you're ripping up and out of your body.

"And following our will and wind we may just go where no one's been.
We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been.
Spiral out. Keep going, going"

Will is the most important attribute in astral projection. You must tell yourself you ARE going to project. Keep pushing and pushing. Don't let the fear of the spiraling sensation overcome your will. Ride the spiral out to push through to the other side and experience something that no one will ever experience the same way.

comment_37: This is quite possibly the most complex and universal song I have ever heard in my life. The centerpiece of this masterpiece is the concept of the Fibonacci Spiral; which is a shape that spans across the cosmos, from the DNA that is the foundation of our human forms, to the spiral arms that hold the stars above us ("as below so above and beyond I imagine"). However, there is a spiral that is on an even larger scope than that of the Fibonacci Spiral, and that is the Spiral of Evolution. The process of Evolution is merely the physical manifestation of something larger. Evolution is a process to describe only one organism, and that is the Self. We are all riding the Spiral of Evolution through the process of reincarnation. Each time we return to physical reality, we evolve a little more spiritually while simultaneously contributing to the physical process of evolution. "Black then white are all I see" refers to the duality consciousness of the brain. "Red and yellow then came to be" is the first and third chakras which are survival instinct and power leading one to question the limited paradigm of pure duality. Over-thinking things limits the power of our feelings and/or intuition which are much more powerful than intellect alone. All limits are merely waiting to be transcended through pushing the envelope. Sucking in the sounds of the universe will change you much quicker and more intensely than absorbing light through your eyes ("open wide to suck it in, I feel it move across my skin"). Cymatics is the science of how sound manipulates, sustains, as well as generates reality. "Reaching out to embrace whatever may come" is the acceptance and merging of the individual consciousness with cosmic consciousness (or the consciousness that powers the universe). "We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been" refers to the concept that we are all portions of Source/God/Consciousness/Spirit/Awareness, and so we desire to ride the spiral of evolution until Source can know itself in all forms and perspectives without going insane (for we are one with Source). Until that time, all we can do is spiral out.

I heard Maynard talking about this song on a Joe Rogan podcast recently. He said the Fibonacci sequence was sort of an afterthought when they were writing this song, as he's not an expert on mathematics, but he sees the beauty of mathematics and nature, such as the Golden Ratio explored in Da Vinci's works. Although most mathematicians wouldn't claim the Golden Ratio is perfectly evident in nature, it does approximate it in many supposed instances, which is quite profound. Maynard is a very thoughtful and unique thinker. This track, to me, explores what he believes makes life worthwhile: finding the power of beauty, whether that's through art, music, mathematics, or personal relationships:

"I embrace my desire to
Feel the rhythm, to feel connected
Enough to step aside and weep like a widow
To feel inspired
To fathom the power
To witness the beauty
To bathe in the fountain
To swing on the spiral
To swing on the spiral to

Swing on the spiral
Of our divinity 
And still be a human"

Although Maynard is not a religious guy at all, I believe he still sees "divinity" in a way that invokes a notion of spirituality. He believes in something more than this materialistic world but, again, is not religious, and certainly not an adherent to monotheistic religion. You can appreciate the way religious individuals have referred to human nature as divine without needing to take their doctrines as factual. For example, the appreciation you have of the Sistine Chapel is enhanced if you empathise with Michelangelo's religious beliefs when you stand under his art, and whether you are religious yourself or not is irrelevant. Maynards notion of spirituality is closer to Eastern religions, hence why he talks about the Third Eye, and so forth. His appeal to mysticism doesn't necessarily mean he believes in a spiritual realm, but I believe he thinks one exists. I wouldn't bet on that; however, and I also wouldn't say Maynard is a convinced atheist.

Especially interesting is Maynard's adulation of creativity: "infinite possibilities". That's something inherently human â that we can dream up, imagine, and meditate on infinite possibilities, occurring on an endless spiral, and I imagine he could be referring to the infiniteness of fractals in this sense, which are present in much of Tool's artworks.

comment_53:
Tool consider themselves artists and rightly so:
True art always has a differing impact on its audience as it allows us to draw not only from what is before us, but also into ourselves and from our own life experiences to form an interpretation.
Look at all the different opinions of this song as an example of that.

To me this song does initially look at our perception of the world when we are young. Black and white represents opposites, good and evil, light and dark, and both are very straightforward shades, rather than colours â because colours represent depth and complexity. 
As we mature we begin to realise that the world is more than simply black and white. Not only does âred and yellowâ represent the complexity of our world, but also the growth of the human ability to search and strive to understand our surroundings and the development of a... soul, if you like, which longs to know why we are here, what we are destined to become â all the things that we can spend a lifetime searching for and possibly never discover.

Thus the line, âover thinking, over analysing, separates the body from the mindâ. As we become too engrossed on what may be, we miss out on what is and what could be if only we were smart enough to recognise the opportunity. 
The body is our physical form that will be with us in this life time and it is affected by all that is physical and tangible here on earth while we are alive.  And yet it is with our mind that we explore other existences and possibilities and exercise lateral thinking. I like what Hoomanha said â âThe eye is not aware it is an eye, but the brain isâ. The brain is our powerhouse of understanding, but our bodies allow us the amazing earthly experiences such as sight and hearing and touch. Humans have a mere pinpoint in an eternity to experience these things and yet we take a lot of it for granted; instead entwining ourselves by trying to understand the âbigger pictureâ. Maynard isnât accusing humanity and saying that we are wrong for doing this â he no doubt does it himself - but simply making an observation of humanity and encouraging us to look at our lives and what we are from a different perspective. 

As the song draws closer to the end it incorporates terms such as âweepâ, âwitnessâ, âbatheâ âfeel (it move across my skin)â. These are all bodily experiences. Maynard also speaks of embracing a desire to feel connected. I think this is a willingness to experience a unity between mind and spirit and thus enjoying a fulfilled and satisfying life, knowing that you have embraced both to the best of your ability.     
Despite the reference to âriding a spiralâ being a key point of this song, I donât think Iâm certain enough about my own opinion of what it might mean to include it.

A fantastic song. I have a lot of respect for this band â cant wait to see them live.

I think Maynard would laugh at a lot of the stuff that people write here.  Especially when they try to relate it to Maynards own life.  People do come up with some pretty good possible meanings, but when Maynard was writing these songs he probably had only one meaning in mind.

Don't you think it's funny how people argue over the song meanings and get so angry.  The fact is that a song means whatever the listener wants it to mean, so there is no right and wrong interpretation.  Maynard writes a song about something that he feels and puts it out there on his albums, but there is no way that he could know how people are going to respond to or interpret it.  There's no way anyone can calculate all possible reactions of any public work because you do not think like everyone else.  So go ahead and write what you want to write.  If people flip out then they flip out, if people agree then they agree, it's that simple.  It doesn't mean that you shouldn't have said it.  If no one ever said or done anything offensive we would still be living in a dictatorship as serfs.  It's just important that you don't hold grudges against other people. There's some funny stuff here. Nobody's really wrong, but it's good to see people with active imaginations. Since I didn't see it mentioned specifically, I'll just toss in my little tidbit here. The spiral mentioned in the song refers to the spiral resulting from the fibonacci sequence. This sequence of numbers is present in all different forms of life, especially plants. Another spiral, the golden mean spiral, is part of sacred geometry, and is considered perfect. As the spirals progress they come very close to being the same spiral, and some people think this is no coincidence. Life is constantly trying to become greater, to become perfect. So if we "ride the spiral to the end" the spirals may become one and we may just become perfect, or become greater than we can imagine. In short, we, as humans, may very well be capable of doing anything. Keep going. 

I don't think this is a case of over-analyzing, as it's mentioned specifically by the band here and there.

comment_103:
A masterpiece of a song.  Takes an extremely talented group of people to perform a song like this one, with sections in the 7/8 time measure.  The lyrics are more than meaningful.  The entire message of the album Lateralus and the song that is its namesake is unity, I think, and evolution of the human race.  "To feel connected" is to live together as one race, seeing the beauty, power, and feeling the rhythm of the oneness and unity everyone can feel.  Spiralling out of our individuality will forth the race to grow out of the bonds of war and greed.  "With my feet upon the ground, I lose myself between the sounds..." Maynard's idea is perceptible and tangible to the world, if only everyone would listen, hence having one's feet firmly planted on the ground, even though their head is in the clouds, represents a kind of metaphor for a reachable goal.

Tool claims the "Lateralis" song name was not intended to be spelt the way it was.  It was a typo of sorts they say.  The working title of Lateralus was "7-8-9" signifying the time measures of the song, and was later named the title track of the album.

And oh yes, antiaverage, Maynard claims it's an odd sound his siamese cat makes recorded and slowed down to make an eerie kind of groaning.  Great song, great album.

k u all might think im way off, but here is what i think and it makes perfect sense to me.  I think tool writes their songs to inspire thought and stuff, but this is what the song means to me.  Alot of it will soud like say humans post because i agree with him on most of his points.

"Black then white are all I see in my infancy 
Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me, let's me see" k when u are born you see black and white then moments later pick up red and then yellow and so on (red and yellow are primary colors so u pick up the rest at about the same time)  I dont think he is actually talking about that crap, cuz no one can remember when they are that young and its all pretty instantaneous.  its a metaphor meaning that at first, you only know right and wrong and aren't influenced by anything, then slowly things become more complex and you need to make more decisions and certain things arent just black and white anymroe....they are red and yellow and other colors too.

"Over thinking, over analyzing, separates the body from the mind Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must Feed my will to feel my moment, drawing way outside the lines"  He is saying that over thinking and over analyzing everything gets rid of your intuition (intuition is defined as knowledge discerned directly by the mind without reasoning or analysis; a truth or revelation arrived at by insight; the power or capacity to percieve truth without apparent reasoning or concentration.) or 'natural or ispired instinct' and you make things too complicated.

"Feed my will to feel this moment, urging me to cross the line 
Reaching out to embrace the random, reaching out to embrace whatever may come " i think he si saying you need to go with your intuition and be inspired by everything around you and take chances, and cross the lines of society and be open to whatever might come to your mind.

"I embrace my 
Desire to 
I embrace my

Our divinity and

well a spiral is definied as something turning around an axis (sommething divine?) and constandly getting closer to it.  so what i think this part of the song is talking about is being able to be godlike and spiritual to yourself and whatnot and be your own person, but in the end still be just a human.

"with my feet upon the ground i lose myself between the sound and open wide to suck it in i feel it move across my skin"  k well i really believe this part and what i think, is that "you lose yourself between the sound" well, where the sound is, is in your ears, and inbetween your ears is your brain, and when you "lose yourself between the sound" you are getting lost in your brain pretty much and just observing everything and "witnessing the beauty" and everything around you.  then when he says "with my feet upon the ground" i think hes sayin "yeah im just a human still, even though divine at the same time" then "open wide to suck it in i feel it move across my skin" he is embracing everything about the experience.

all I see (3)

comment_166: I didn't read everything, but I didn't catch anything on Transcendentalism, which I believe had a heavy influence on the lyrics to this song, and many other works by Tool.  If you don't know what Transcendentalism is, you should look into it.  It was started by Ralph Waldo Emerson, and another significant character in its development is Henry David Thoreau, known most for his civil disobediance. Transcendentalists believe in heavy ties between humans and nature, and the connection between all existance as a single being.  Sort of the Western Buddhism, but that's a very vague relationship.  Good works of Transcendentalism includes Nature by Emerson, and Walden by Thoreau.

I love this song... At first it took some getting used to for me since it was a little different but I disected it by verse so here it is:  

Verse 1:Black then white are all i see in my infancy.
              red and yellow then came to be, reaching 
                        out to me. 
              lets me see.
              as below, so above and beyond, I imagine
              drawn beyond the lines of reason.
              Push the envelope. Watch it bend.

meaning to me:  It means that when he was young he was told (or knew) only two sides (IE right or wrong; left or right; up or down; heaven or hell; et cetera) but as he got older there were other factors (IE diagonal; 'white' lies; purgatory; et cetera) and the other factors called to him; they seemed more free, inviting if you will. They seemed abstract but at the same time normal.

Verse 2:Over thinking, over analyzing separates the 
                body from the mind.
             Withering my intuition, missing 
                 opportunities and I must
              Feed my will to feel my moment drawing 
                  way outside the lines.


meaning to me:  the more you think about something; the more you use reason the less you rely on what you know. It basically says (to me) to live fore the moment every now and then.

verse 3:  same as verse one.

verse 4: over thinking, over analyzing separates the 
                 body from the mind.
            Withering my intuition leaving opportunities 
                   behind.
             Feed my will to feel this moment urging me 
                 to cross the line.
             Reaching out to embrace the random. 
             Reaching out to embrace whatever may 
                   come.


meaning to me: verse 2 and that what your mind/heart knows takes over and lets him go for anything he wants; free from society.

verse 5: I embrace my desire to
            I embrace my desire to
            feel the rhythm, to feel connected enough 
                  to step aside and weep like a widow
            to feel inspired to fathom the power, to 
                 witness the beauty, 
            to bathe in the fountain, 
            to swing on the spiral 
            to swing on the spiral 
            to swing on the spiral of our divinity and still 
                be a human.


meaning to me: he finally gives into what he feels, you know-the beat of life of which you live for. He realizes that religion (whatever form it might be) should be a part of everyone not in one person... you control your destiny.

verse 6:With my feet upon the ground I move myeslf between the sounds and open wide to suck it in. 
I feel it move across my skin. 
I'm reaching up and reaching out. I'm reaching for the random or what ever will bewilder me.
what ever will bewilder me.
And following our will and wind we may just go where no one's been.
We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been.
Spiral out. Keep going.
Spiral out. Keep going.
Spiral out. Keep going.
Spiral out. Keep going.
Spiral out. Keep going.


meaning to me: he realizes where he's at and takes in everything he sees, hears, and feels. He's looking for something new and interesting and when he finds it he intends to take it to the end and be (maybe) the first to do it.

Ok bare with me here this is a bit weird I donât know if anyone has already touched on this with their explanation if they have sorry for posting it again.

After the first few times of listening to this song it reminded me a lot of a book I read called Bewilderness by Palyne Gaenir.  

This book goes on to explain The Rainbow of the soul and this to me seems to have a lot to do with this song.

In the song the opening lines âBlack then white are all I see in my infancy 
Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me, let's me seeâ 

To me these lines symbolise the Rainbow of the soul.  
In the book it describes the soul as a rainbow, like each colour representing a different level of reality E.g.: Yellow is the Mental aspect of reality and red represents the Physical part of your existence.

So with the opening lines I think Maynard is saying you are born with a clean slate Black and White then your notions of Thinking and Felling then come to you making you seen and feel in a different light.

Now in the book it describes your level of physical reality as a line that goes across the rainbow.  The line is a wavy line almost like a sine wave the top of the line and the bottom of the line cross all the plains of the rainbow.  The full rainbow in total represents your full self or your soul.  This means by manipulating the âline of Physical realityâ you can be open to anything that there is in the world that being what you can and cannot see.

This seems to explain to me the next part of the song.

âAs below, so above and beyond, I imagine 
Drawn beyond the lines of reason 
Push the envelope, watch it bend 

Over thinking, over analyzing, separate the body from the mind 
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must 
Feed my will to feel my moment, drawing way outside the linesâ

And in the book it even says and I quote âThe bottom and top loop-ends of the sine wave should be considered infinite in both directions. And there are many of those rainbows above and below "ours."

Thatâs not far away from the actual words in the song.

So I think the song is about using your mind to go to every part of the soul at once then bringing everything together.  So that you can exist in both the Physical and Mental worlds at the same time.

The spiral bit of the song reminds me of the paintings by Alex Grey who done the cover art for the album.  In the paintingâs he represents the path of the soul as a spiral.  So in this song I think Maynard is saying follow your soul and you âmay just go where no one's beenâ.

Ok I know what I mean lol but itâs hard to explain it all.

comment_190:
I think Maynard is talking about human growth, mentally and physically.

"Black then white are all I see in my infancy. Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me, let's me see "  

-  I think he is talking about how when we are young, we don't have the ability to see other perspectives, eg: if you asked a child, "is it right for a mother to steal a loaf of bread to feed her starving kids?" the child would answer that it's either right or wrong, where as if you were to ask an adult, they would be able to look at both sides of the argument like: "well, it is illegal, but at the same time, her kids will starve if she doesn't steal the bread...".

"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine Drawn beyond the lines of reason ". 

-Here I think he is talking about how as we grow we start to become aware of the possibility of the existance of god (in one form or another), the "as above...", referance is from the bible I think, about how whatever we hold true on earth will be the same in heaven.  I think Maynard picked this reference, to demonstrate that while as humans, we all have some notion of an afterlife, our perceptions of it as sculpted by the things we see around us, because ours minds will not stretch beyond that and therefore our perception of the afterlife could be way off because our brains will not allow us to go beyond what we know.

I think the biggest clue to the meaning is in the title.
Seperate the words and you get Lateral Us.

comment_193:
Tool uses mathematical concepts to write their songs.  In this song, they use Pascal's Triangle.  To begin the song, each line contains the number of syllables that equals the sum of the previous two lines:

Black (1)
And (1)
White are (2)
All I see (3)
In my infancy (5)
red and yellow then came to me (8)

comment_199:
To me, the song Lateralus has really no single meaning, but it's more of a gateway to realizing the entire meaning of the album.

Lateralus has a lot of hidden things that when i first bought it, i never realized it had.  Lateralus is more of a key to unlocking it.  Somebody said something about the time signature's being 

9/8,8/8,7/8 = 987 = 19th term in the Fibonacci sequence....

Not only that, but the syllabols of the first verse, 1,1,2,3,5,8... etc... are the first numbers of the same sequence (not Pascal's triangle).

The entire song focuses around spirals, and if you are really bored, you can start fooling around with putting the tracks in a linear order on paper and then trying to pair them with spirals... start with Parabol, Parabola... and keep pairing numbers that equal 13... as follows..

6,7,5,8,4,9,13,1,12,2,11,3,10

13 is kind of an intermission... and it breaks the spiral... as said in the song Lateralus "Spiral out, keep going..."

The freaky thing is that if you listen closely and take out pauses between the song... (dont use MP3's as they dont have good sound quality, but use the CD itself), every song will connect... it's freaky... as Schism ends with that double bass and you can tell Ticks and Leeches follows that same pattern and then as ticks and Leeches flows into Mantra... it almost sounds like dry heaves... or something...

Most of you should hear it for yourself.

I got most of my info on this from google searches of ppl who have done it themselves... if you wanna know more search for "The Lateralus Prophecy"

To conclude, the entire album seems to be talking to us about our spiritual side... or the other side of us (Laterus-Us), or at least that's what it means to me.

Bare with me because this is my first post. I'll give a rather long interpretation of the song IMHO:

Firstly, I don't know if any of you have heard of the Fibonacci Sequence - The Golden Ratio - a mathematical equation which basically, when graphed, creates a spiral. 1,1,2,3,5,8,13... and so on - you add the number that came before the last to get the next number - simple, which creates a spiral that has the same proportions as the numbers, look it up on Google :o) Anyhoo, Maynard sings the lyrics throughout the ENTIRE song in syllables of those numbers.
"Black, and, white are, all I see, in my in-fan-cy, red and yell-ow than came to be" (1,1,2,3,5,8)  than back down the sequence, "reach-ing- out to me, lets me see." (5,3)
Just an example, but you will find on listening that the entire song goes like this. At the end Maynard says "Spiral out, keep going... etc." "Ride the spiral to the end it may just go where no ones been" etc. Okay so the song is obviously based on something geometrical/ mathematical (Sacred Geometry as we all know Danny Carey is interested in?) And has to do with the Fibonacci sequence (maybe not totally but has some sort of relation.) Note also that the Fibonacci Sequence is also sometimes referred to as the Universal Equation, because the spiral it creates can be found throughout nature in many significant places. The spiral that the Milky Way creates is an exact replica, the spiral in the seeds at the end of a sunflower, the spiral on a seashell, all exact replicas which is why the Golden Ratio, The Fibonacci Sequence, is under so much study even today. Anyyyyhooo sorry to get off subject but this does relate.

So Maynard says black than white are all I see in my infancy red and yellow than came to be. We are born (infancy) seeing only black and white the simple colors.  The most basic colors. Than we eventually see red and yellow - the deeper parts of life. (Religion, belief, emotion, values, whatever you want to refer that to) "lets me see" He says. (THIRD EYE ANYONE? The clairvoyance chakra)

So this song IMHO is DEFINITELY based on spiritual accentuation.

"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine -Everything
Drawn beyond the lines of reason -(Faith - believing without reason)
Push the envelope, watch it bend" -(Dig deeper into spirituality and watch how it (bends)  works for lack of a better word.)


Over thinking, over analyzing, separate the body from the mind -Take things at face value (I tend to apply this to my own interpretations of what Maynard really means in his songs. Specifically in Lateralus, and I find that it seems to work well.)
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must -(Corroding that which makes us human. Intuition. Read some Deepak Chopra books)
Feed my will to feel my moment, drawing way outside the lines (Referring to bending the envelope once again)

Feed my will to feel this moment (Use this part of the song maybe ? or the music itself? Keep in mind the fibonacci sequence as well as Danny Carey's use of sacred geometry in his drumming especially during this  stanza)
Urging me to cross the line (Persuading you to feel rather than over analyze)
Reaching out to embrace the random (infinite possibilities)
Reaching out to embrace whatever may come (embrace everything, as in the next stanze)

I embrace my->
Desire to
I embrace my->
Desire to
Feel the rhythm, to (the rhythm of life, love, the universe - Merkaba)
Feel connected (Once again Deepak Chopra books)
Enough to step aside and (Step outside of everyday life)
Weep like a widow, to  (FEEL EMOTION, EMBRACE LIFE)
Feel inspired, to  "
Fathom the power, to  "
Witness the beauty, to  "
Bathe in the fountain, to  "
Swing on the spiral, to  "   (Fibonacci, The Universal Equation)
Swing on the spiral, to "  "

Swing on the spiral of
Our divinity and (Divinity - of, relating to, or proceeding directly from God or a god - spirituality)
Still be a human (Yet still be physically on earth - lateral)

With my feet upon the ground I move myself between the sounds (Feet upin the ground referring once again to being a human, physically on the ground)
And open wide to suck it in, I feel it move across my skin (Release reasion. OPEN your mind WIDE to suck it in)
I'm reachin' up and reachin' out, I'm reachin' for the random or (Reach for and embrace the random the rhythm of life)
Whatever will bewilder me, whatever will bewilder me
And following our will and wind, we may just go where no one's been (Wherever the wind takes you, maybe you'll will achieve a sort of enlightenment)
