comment_214: This is a brilliant song, they're best to date i reckon. I think its about expanding your horrizons and taking the oppertunities that are presented to you
comment_215:
Check out books about quantum physics and how it relates to metaphysics, concepts about space and time and our relationship to it, and how it enables us to literally create our own reality. Titles: Self-Aware Universe- I lent the book out so I can't think of the author. There are so many other books out there on this subject. I have also read Deepak Chopras "The Spontaneous Fulfillment of Desire" and "The Way of the Wizard" which has changed my perception and expanded my reality. Reality is a lot bigger than we think it is- our perceptions are so limited. Another major shift more me is finally grasping the concept of the Eternal Now. Time and space is not what we imagine it to be- not by a long shot. 

So my study in this area has enriched my perspective of this song, and this song has given color and emotion and feel and sound and fleshed out my intellectual readings. There of course, other other songs and films that have done the same. Funny how all these things show up just when we need it. 

I am determined to see the universe the way a mystic sees it- even if it only lasts for a few seconds. It can be done. Spiral out!
comment_216: To me, this song is about whatever I want it to be about when I'm in a particular mood. If I'm anger, this song is about hate. If I'm happy, it's about enjoying life. If I'm curious, it's about branching out. This is an absolutely fabulous song.
comment_217:
Understanding
I do believe that Tool's songs are intended for something more so than one specific interpretation. Also playing in band doing alot of Tool's songs, I do think they are for people to also think for themselves, giving a message. To understand this I red this article that explains a hell of alot. And before anyone specifically interprets any Tool songs, read this if haven't already read it yourself somewhere else.......

To me, Tool's Lateralus is the most amazing piece of music ever composed. I think Tool deliberately wanted to give their fans something truly amazing, but wanted them to find it on their own. "Recognize this as a holy gift..." At first, I thought that the song Lateralus was about tripping acid - discovering true color by seperating the body from the mind. At first listen, I imagined the bending envelope as an intense visual. After becoming more familiar with the track, however, I had reformed my interpretation to something broader: think deeper. Lateralus, perhaps because it is the album's "title track", serves as the central clue for a puzzle that a friend of mine had read about somewhere on the internet. "All I know is that there is a different order for the songs - something about two spirals. Oh yeah, and thirteen is in the middle." After scavenging through endless google search results, I gave up on finding more about this 'alternate order'. Intent to figure the album out, and very curious about the spirals - I put on the proverbial 'thinking cap'. I understood how the spirals could have a lot of significance, in that the album's title track offers the inspiring, "swing on the spiral of our divinity and still be a human..........And following our will and wind we may just go where no one's been. We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been." In my internet scavenging, I had read one review, written by a drummer, who mentioned that Danny Carey's drum beat formed a fibonacci sequence during the song Lateralus. A drummer myself, I decided to get out the graph paper and follow Danny. I can't play like he can, but at least I can hear everything he's doing, and thus was able to construct the drum tabulature. Sure enough, Danny repeats a Fibonacci sequence through the number 13: 1,1,2,3,5,8,13. After 13, he starts again with 1. Bringing in my Algebra 2 knowledge of the Fibonacci sequence, when the equation for the Fibonacci sequence (which I don't actually know) is graphed, it forms a sprial whose vertex depends on the number at which the sequence begins. Coincidence? I began to think not. I had already known of Danny's obsession with sacred geometry and am familiar with Bob Frissell's book, Nothing in This Book Is True, But It's Exactly How Things Are , so the significance of what I had stumbled upon had actually begun to settle in. This is where I just had to play with Lateralus. I had doodled a few spirals in the corners of my graph paper, and in doing so made the first important connection to Lateralus. I knew that if the tracks were in fact intended to be heard in a different order, "Parabol" and "Parabola" would have to go together. In drawing my spirals, I had begun with a vertex and 'spiraled' outwards. After writing the numbers 1 through 13 linearly, I could immediately see that Parabol and Parabola would have to be the middle of my spiral (in that 13 / 2 = 6.5). I drew a simple arrow between 6 and 7 and then pondered the next pair. At first, I actually drew a spiral connecting pairs of numbers whose sum equaled 13 (the number of songs on the album). This, however, left the last track in the same position and without anything to connect to. At this time, I had used my copy of Lateralus and Cool Edit Pro to take out the silences between tracks and put the songs in the following order: 6,7,5,8,4,9,3,10,2,11,1,12,13. The transition from Parabola into Schism blew my mind, as the plucks, probably dismissed by listeners as a drawn out rant of an ending, perfectly transition into the beginning of Schism. When you count out beats as the strings are plucked, Schism resumes with the same time signature and tempo - mirroring the progression of notes. The transition from Schism into Ticks & Leeches is equally intriguing. Schism ends with strong double-kick bass and tom smacks, and Ticks & Leeches begins with what many would call a 'tribal' drum beat. The beat at the very start of Ticks & Leeches is slightly different every subsequent time it is repeated - the measures are two beats longer. Yup - you guessed it - those two beats are ACTUALLY the last two beats of Schism. I can honestly say that I never understood the album's fourth track, Mantra until reordering the album's songs. What I had originally heard as whale calls now had begun to resemble the worst imaginable dry heaves - or a stylized choking. Fitting, seeing as how the last line in Ticks & Leeches is "I hope you choke." After this transition, none of those following it really seemed to make much sense. I certainly didn't like that Disposition and Reflection had been seperated - as they sound quite good when played sequentially on the album. This was the only real roadblock in my disciphering of the Holy Gift. Then I had remembered what my friend had told me - 13 was in the middle. At the time, probably just wanting to believe that there was more to this cd, I had equated this to the positioning of the song "Intermission" on the previous release, Ãnema. For the song to be in the 'middle' of the album it would have to be the seventh track in sequence, here having six tracks on either side of it. So I inserted Faaip de Oiad after Lateralus, and almost peed my pants when I discovered that (ever-so-faintly) the fading tone of the last note of Lateralus could be heard in beginning of Faaip de Oiad, and how the distortion of the guitars at the tail end of Lateralus resembled, and later transitioned seamlessly into, the static at the beginning of Faaip de Oiad. The lyrics of Lateralus justify this break in the spiral, almost instructing: "spiral out, keep going, spiral out, keep going." I went back to Lateralus to find the next clue. In Danny Carey's amazingly competent Fibonacci sequence, he had stopped at 13 and gone back to 1. This is what I chose to do to finish the sequence. A second spiral was now constucted, and the order for the Holy Gift now became 6,7,5,8,4,9,13,1,12,2,11,3,10. Already many of you are probably fascinated at what I have revealed to you, but I can not even begin to tell you what this new order has opened up for me. The beauty of Lateralus is very, very fragile and has to be viewed with a very open mind. It can also be different when looked at from different points of view. Aside from the fact that the new order of the songs places them in an order where they flow together nicely - often ending and resuming on the same notes or within the same progression, and some times - in the case of Lateralus into Faaip de Oiad and The Grudge into Triad - even overlapping (though admittadly sound much better when actually electronically overlapped, this is kind of cheating. Consider this a hint, however, if you plan on doing this yourself), the two spirals help to tell a story that every Tool fan should hear. In the interest of not boring the only casually intrigued, I will try to keep this very brief. I would also recommend familiarizing yourselves with Frissell's book (yeah - the one I mentioned earlier). I consider Parabol and Parabola to be quite expository. Maynard wants us to know that no matter what happens, we must all know that this is not our only existance. Our very minds and the contents of our subconscious are intended to be immortal, and if we accept this into our lives (be it because of personal or religious reasons), it will be so. As such, pain is an illusion. At first, I called it "The Lateralus Prophecy" (for reasons you will soon understand), but I have since decided to call the 'reordered' version of Lateralus "The Holy Gift". As Maynard says, "Recognize this as a holy gift and celebrate this chance to be alive and breathing," I take the word "this" to mean much more than just his simple cautioning. Since Parabola is the second track of the Holy Gift, it can be considered at the beginning (esp. considering the context of it's duality with Parabol), and as such, I interpret Maynard's words as more than just clever lyrics in a song. They are a plead for his listeners to listen to everything he has to say and truly celebrate the chance of immortality offered throughout. I would be lying if I said that each song has a specific translation. On the contrary, Tool's music is designed to make you think, not say something specific. It must be treated like great literature - much is hidden contextually. I will elude to Geometric-Drumming's previous post, where he explains the time signatures of Schism: "It represents the title...it's arranged in 12/8 time which is SPLIT into 5/8 and 7/8 - which only really FITS as you PUT THE PIECES BACK TOGETHER." Where Geometric-Drumming claims Schism as his favorite Tool song, I have heard some fans say that it was a retched pick for the album's only single - but I think it was brilliant. Not to downplay the interpretations of those who have posted before me (in fact, I agree with much of what %BlueSoulRobot% has to say), but I think that to the casual listener who knows nothing of Tool, it can be a powerful invitation. Think about it - a lot of dingbats with MTV and a radio would walk around with the words "I know the pieces fit" in their heads. I wonder how many of them took the time to put the pieces back together to (re)discover what is trying to be communicated. I welcome any feedback. I would love to share interpretations of the songs via email - just too lengthy to post here. I would like to offer the following advice: DO NOT use MP3s to digitally reorder Lateralus. A lot of VERY IMPORTANT information is encoded on the actual cd. Ever notice how everyone who has lost or broken that cd has IMMEDIATELY gone out and bought a new copy? I know I have. It's because there are things encoded on the factory pressing of the cd that are lost in the mp3 compression process and any direct copy onto a cd-r. If you want to do it, do it right - I can't stress how important this is. Use the cda tracks as you put it together and maintain all audio fidelity using professional mixing software. 

There's a Fibonacci in Maynard's lyrics, specifically the syllables: 

black [1] 

then [1] 

white are [2] 

all I see [3] 

in my infancy [5] 

red and yellow then came to be [8] 

reaching out to me [5] 

lets me see [3] 

there is [2] 

so [1] 

much [1] 

more and [2] 

beckons me [3] 

to look through to these [5] 

infinite possibilities [8] 

as below so above and beyond I imagine [13] 

drawn outside the lines of reason [8] 

push the envelope [5] 

watch it bend [3] 

I suppose it's not actually a true Fibonacci, since it does reverse itself. 

the Fibonacci Sequence. It's basically a string of numbers that when you add a number to the number before it, you get the next number. Starting with the numbers 0 and 1. 0+1=1, so the set now looks like this; 0 1 1. You take the 1 and add the previous number (1) and you get 2. The sequence looks like this; 0 1 1 2. Now you take the 2 and add the previous number and get 3. Now you have 0 1 1 2 3. When you add the 3 and the 2 you get 5. 0 1 2 3 5. 5+3=8. 0 1 1 2 3 5 8. The process continues

comment_222:
I am listening to schism right now- the pieces are starting to fit!  

Thank you for the input on fibonacci sequences. For those who say get a life, this sacred geometry thing is more common than one would think. Artists have used it (I think Leonardo da Vinci, and others as well) Industrial designers, and graphic desginers use this type of math all the time. I have several books on mathmatics and the geometry of design. ( I used to be a graphic designer) Architecture is often based on these numbers. This pattern appears in nature as well- the human body, crystals, and of course, the nautilus shell. There are a lot of layers to anything we listen to or see. Which level one decides to go to us up to them. 

For those who choose to just look at the surface of things, of course things like the rhythm of a haiku poem or how a base riff compliments a vocal line or how certain melodic intervals or harmonies affect us on an emotional level or how a certain time signature makes us feel balanced or slightly off balance, or how our body can actually mimic these rhythms, or how we percieve stability and elegance in certain structural proportions, or exactly where the eye is going to be drawn to in a perfect visual composition  is going to be lost on you. Leave these discussions to the artists that actually create. Others are obviously on this planet to mindlessly consume. 

There is elegant subtlety in all forms of art. If you want to pick it up on a subliminal level, just listen. If you want to create, be open to receive inspiration from EVERYTHING UNDER THE SUN. This is why I am fascinated by math and physics- there is beauty in it. I am also reading about myths and stories- anything you put your mind to can resurface somewhere in your art, whatever that is. What is your life's work? Creating can be simple or complicated, but one must remain aware and open-minded, remaining "open wide to suck it in" so to speak. 

I am a drummer as well, although not in the same league as you all, I certainly appreciate the passion for rhythm.  

The ones who say just get a fucking life do not understand that much of art, whether it be drumming, dancing, or architecture is based not just on what is, but what isn't. (silence, space) Someone who doesn't know any better will create an ad filled with as much crap as possible with little regard for the element of space- or rely on a template. A songwriter - most pop songs- will rely on a template as well. There is no temporal tension, or sensititvity as to where gaps or silences, no matter how small, should be placed. The whole world is really rhythm, if you think about it. Snowflakes, industrial design, poetry, music, tides, biorhythms. 

If nobody understood and really thought about time and space in this matter, we would all still be in the dark ages. Anyone want to tell Leonardo da Vinci to get a life? 

As far as overthinking, overanalyzing: 

Once this stuff soaks into your subconscious, you then release it and watch what resurfaces- the body and the mind then join. You have to explore the external world first, then let the subconscious take over, to a certain degree. But to not even explore, and condemn others for doing so, is just sad. 

Keep pushing the envelope, guys. Thanks for some new perspectives, thanks for being awake and aware and alive and breathing. Thank God.
comment_223:
Taking another break from my work here..

Anyone who thinks we are playing too much with numbers should study classical music theory. No parallel 4ths or 5ths, a certain harmonic chord progression must be observed, and many more mathematical rules. (If only Ashlee simpson could tell Mozart to get a life!)  And the math behind the music of Tool is part of what makes them what they are! Even Pop music has math in it, even though it's more like 2+2=4, abab structure, boring, undynamic, formulaic stuff with no suprises or tension, with a few exceptions. Like it or not, math and art often merge, and what we think is pure intuition or feeling is a result of careful study, even if those rules are eventually broken. (Picasso, jazz theory) OK, I'm going to get some coffee and get some work done!

Peace and Light!

I'd love to put my interpretation down but Madson4562 wrote a flawless one.  Exactly what it means.  It's toward the begining of the post, but trust me its worth reading.  

It amazes sometimes.  Tool and Maynard puts things down in music that every person feels at some point and makes it beautiful.  Some songs i don't really like because of lyrical content, but this song I do.  Its probably one of the best individual songs out period.  So much is felt and experienced in this one song, it'll take a while before i will complete understand it by going through all of my own experieces in my life.  

The biggest point in this song is the combination of phsyical life and spiritual life.  To me this is a necessity to live.  Without a spiritual life, then what is there to live for.  We are all people, imperfect and unholy as ever, but with that higher being, with God there are answers.  You just have to open yourself to the answers, and of course all the answers come from God.  Its not easy to let go of your pride or sense of superiority, but in all reality this life is just the begining of something greater.  

Let go, spiral out, and see where it will lead you.

Okay, umm, my last comment was deleted because of server issues, so I guess I'll have to repost it.

I obtained this from songfacts.com:

"The line "Black then white are all I see in my infancy, red and yellow then came to be" has to do the the Maori Aborigines from Australia who at first did art work only with black and white paints then later discovered how to make red and yellow, which they incorporated in their art. The "Spiral" would probably be either the earth twisting on its axis or its rotation around the sun. (thanks, Jake - New Jersey, NJ)"

Seems to make sense if you look at it from the surface. Going deeper would unlock new meanings, but that's most likely where Tool got the idea to write such lines from.

comment_249:
Here's what the song means to me:

Following along with what "reverand_chris" posted three years ago, I have to believe that what he's saying is correct, and this is why:

Overthinking and overanalyzing is what people do to Tool's songs all the time, when it's probably just a simple meaning that Maynard is trying to get across.

Also, the connection with divinity and still being a human, to me, has to do with the glitz and glamour of becoming a star.  For instance, some big stars (i.e. Britney Spears) get caught up in the glamour of being a star, so people begin to worship them and accept them as almost divine beings.

I think this song has to do more with Tool's evolution over the years from CD to CD, starting with Opiate and ending with Lateralus.  If you listen to all their CDs, you can tell EASILY that Tool has changed.  You can tell they've come from this angry, screamy group to this more mature, mellow group who really don't have to scream to get their points across.

Reaching out to embrace the random and what's said around that has more to do with what's to come from Tool.

As reverand_chris said, embracing the desire to feel the rhythm and the lyrics thereafter have to do with, yes, feeling the music and being able to "weep like a widow" at the lyrics.  "Feeling it".

Lateralus was the first Tool CD I bought, and I must've bought it when it first came out.  I've since purchased their other CDs, and I admit it, when I first started listening to Tool, I thought they were this evil, devil worshiping group, but now I understand that they aren't, and that (some of) their music has deep meaning, and it keeps me buying and listening...

But, hell, of course I could be wrong, just like everyone else.  I just don't think people are thinking outside the box for this song and think it does have some really deep meaning, I've read what other people think.. thinking black and white have to do with babies in the womb and such.. but.. nyeh.  I don't know why Maynard would sing about that.

More power to you if that's what you think. =P

comment_257:
To understand this song completely a knowledge of the occult is first required. The line "as below, so above" seems to me a twist on the old saying "as above, so below" a saying popular amoung many medieval mystics.
Although most Tool songs can be interperated in many different ways I believe with this song there is one true meaning and all the other meanings are just metaphors for the real meaning. 
This "true" meaning is about human evolution and more importantly the evolution of our concious mind, to make this song more complex it seems to be related to the growth of a human being. 
To understand the first line it should be noted that many people believe several thousand years ago human beings could not see as many colours as they do now. There is plenty of evidence for this, Homer talks about the sea being the same colour as wine for example. Once you take this into account "Black then white are all I see in my infancy 
Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me, let's me see" seems to make perfect sense.
To analyze every single line would be tedious and would miss the point of the actual song.
This song is about evolution, and not about the streight scientific Darwin "natural selction" theory of evolution (which would have us believe that evolution is directionless and devoid of any meaning).
It is talking about evolution as more of a work of art, with a destination. 
"Spiral out, keep going" means we just keep moving forward.

To me, the song is simply about appriciating life for what it is, and enjoying it. Lets take a look...

"Black then white are all I see in my infancy.
red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me.
lets me see."
Anyone else notice that the colors mentioned are the traditional "skin tones?" What does that have to do with it? I'm not sure.

"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
drawn beyond the lines of reason.
Push the envelope. Watch it bend."
In other words, open your eyes to other possibilities... what you don't see. What you can't see.

"Over thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind.
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must
Feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines."
Don't think... feel. Don't stay within the boundaries of society. This song means a LOT to me... so much that I can't put it into words.

"Feed my will to feel this moment urging me to cross the line.
Reaching out to embrace the random.
Reaching out to embrace whatever may come"
Take things as they are.

"I embrace my desire to
feel the rhythm, to feel connected
enough to step aside and weep like a widow
to feel inspired, to fathom the power,
to witness the beauty, to bathe in the fountain,
to swing on the spiral
of our divinity and still be a human."
Like I said... its about appriciating life.

"With my feet upon the ground I lose myself
between the sounds and open wide to suck it in,
I feel it move across my skin.
I'm reaching up and reaching out,
I'm reaching for the random or what ever will bewilder me.
And following our will and wind we may just go where no one's been.
We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been."
Extra sensory... senses. Sense your enviornment. Simple, yet so very complex. Branch out... SPIRAL out.

This explanation of Lateralus by Z3RO666, I think, is an excellent interpretation. Gotta love this song. It never gets old.

anyone pick up on the lyrical similarities to radiohead's "everything in it's right place"?

the song tells the story of kid a's birth and he says "there are two colours in my head". the two colours, presumably black & white, demonstrate how at birth our perceptions are somewhat pure and defined, whereas it's not until we grow older that we pick up on the grey areas. 

here maynard tells us that he starts by seeing in black & white (i.e. right & wrong, optimism & pessism etc) and then later sees more colours - red (blood, voilence possibly?) and yellow (unsure what yellow is supposed to represent).

This song to me clearly represents two things that Tool have been portraying in Aenima and Lateralus:

1. Astral Projection
2. Third Eye opening

Ever since Paul D'amour left tool has been really spiritual Lol.

Okay first the main thing of astral projection is to have your mind wide awake and keep your body fast asleep so that the mind can separate from the body. "Over thinking, over analyzing, separate the body from the mind " This is an actual method (not a good one) used for astral travel. It keeps your mind fully active. And what he means by the next line is that he has to forget about the future and past and focus on now to get through. Its basically a message to all Astral Travelers

The whole "I embrace my..." is  how desperate people are to get out. and how they will do anything to get out.

The rest of the song is a method to open your third eye. you try to get energy from the earth or the moon into your chakra, and how does he do this? By "Reaching up and reaching out!". this same thing could also be used as an astral projection method where you try to hurl yourself out.
But for the most part this whole song is about astral projection. You feel like you are spinning when approaching exit, so to swing on the spiral would make sense. 

To climb the spiral to the end is to not let the vertigo interfere with your body and lose trying to get out basically. And to go where nobody's been is to finnally spiral out and keep going into the astral. 

This song as well as Parabol/Parabola are both about Astral Projection, it seems as though maynard has mastered the art. :) for those of you traveling, meet him lol

comment_321: La Te Ra Lu S.  These are periodic elements.  Some believe a mixture of these is needed to find an answer to the song or possibly a message is in the numbers of the elements.  The closest idea is that if you translate these into Latin and Greek you get:  LA: Lanthanum - "lie hidden beneath"    TE: Tellurium - "the earth"  RA: Radium - "light"  LU: Lutetium - "the Latin name for Paris"   S: Sulphur - "hellfire"  After adding some articles and connecting verbs we get:  "Hidden beneath the earth, the light of Paris, is hellfire."  What does this mean?  Well, it may have something to do with the church, the "Rennes le Chateou" an old church with a dark and secret past dealing with the Priory of Zion and supposed hidden treasure.  Tool has somewhat of an obsession with this place and supposedly wrote most of this album in a studio in Paris near here.

I know Tool for a while, but I only knew "Schism" and "The Grudge" which I thought were totally different from other metal music. I'm now a Tool fan in one month time after I saw a concert of them in Belgium (I'm from there so...) and I can't get enough of them. Most metal lyrics are easily to understand, even though they can be seen as poetry. But with Tool, I really had to sing along with the lyrics beside me, or else I could not follow completely. And when you know them out of your head, you're starting to think what it could possibly mean. And that moment is so precious. When you think or know the meaning of the song, you feel wiser in a spiritual sense. You accomplished to reach a higher level through thinking deeper. It's like a spiritual orgasm. 
This is one of my favourite Tool songs, it sounds beautiful, the writing is sublime and Maynard's voice is just hypnotic. The use of the Fibonacci numbers and to describe life as a spiritual, divine thing or even as a blessing is such a hopeful message. Singing this song out loud, is my meditation. 
Tool is definitely the band for me, this spiritual progressive metal music is something I'm willing to believe in and it makes me feel alive. And I think a lot of people feel the same way about it.
comment_328:
Lately I've been dealing with an emotional crisis of sorts.  I'm completely smitten with this completely awesome girl, who apparently feels pretty much the same about me as I do about her.  The problem though, is that she's moving to another city to go to school within the next week, and neither one of us is willing to get into a long distance relationship, so we don't really know where we stand at this point.  I've been struggling with this for a few days, brooding, and turning options over and over in my head as is my wont, searching for resolution to my own internal conflict in this issue.  To at least some extant, I have found my resolution in this song.

The song follows a sort of psychological progression of thought.  The colors black and white are the extremes of the color spectrum.  The significance here is that in his 'infancy', before gaining experience and wisdom, the speaker thinks only in absolutes.  Always, never, forever, etc.  In the next line, "red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me, lets me see," the speaker realizes that there is more to life than the stark absolutes of always and never.  Essentially, this song is about learning to take life as it comes.  Its about learning to not try and cram life in to a little box and try to force it to fit your preconception of what it should be.  Its about reaching out to embrace whatever may come.  I feel reasonably sure that when he wrote, Maynard's meaning is much more specific and personal as I think is the case with most of the things he writes.  However, when an artist publish a work, then it is up for interpretation.  It is up to the listener to decide what it means to him or her.  For me, this song has shown me that I must reach out and embrace whatever may come between me and this girl.  I don't presume to claim that this is the only interpretation of this song.  I think everyone needs to decide what it means for themselves.

This song is definately one of Tool's better songs. It is a masterwork.

To me, this song descripes a way of living, a way we ought to live.
The human nature is cold and calculating - only take a step if you are sure you are stepping on solid ground.
The animal nature is full of feelings and intuition, doing what feels right in that exact moment.

In the beginning he sings about the development from the animal nature an infant possesses, to the full thinking analyzing human he eventually turns in to.
Then he goes: "Over thinking, over analyzing seperates the body from the mind, withering my intuition missing oppertunities behind."

comment_367:
Ok. Here's my interpretation of this song. First let me go off on a quick, yet important tangent.)) Of course there is no way to say for sure if this or that is really what the song is about because more than likely the song was constructed to HAVE multiple meanings and to represent multiple things simultaneously.

But when an artist writes lyrics for a song, especially a thinking artist like Maynard or Adam, they have inspiration. Something they feel strongly about that inspires them to "paint with words".

So what do we know they have studied in the past?
Well most interesting to me...PSYCHOLOGY. Jungian Psychology to be specific (46&2). And it wasn't that I had studied Jungian psychology first, and then recognized the meaning behind songs like 46&2, but rather the inverse. The song and it's lyrics pushed me to research about these things. That's the true power of art! The members of Tool are amazing artists because they can invoke thought, learning, self exploration which is tough to pull off. And it is my goal as a musician to do the same. That's true art. I have never listened to Britney Spears and then, inspired by the lyrics, gone out and learned about some new theories on globalization or physics...

And before getting to Lateralus. I want to make one point about people idolizing and worshipping Tool. I'm not bashing anybody for doing it. I've done it myself! It's almost hard not to do. With so many great lyrics and such inspiration, cleansing, spiritual motivations to take from their songs. You almost want to call Maynard God and take everything he says as fact, as the way...but of course doing so would go against everything Maynard and the members of Tool believe in. Freewill. Questioning authority. Point being, question everything they say, as you would with anyone else, hold their words up to a bright light and form your own opinions. Maynard's lyrics are not a new bible for you or for me.

And why do fans feel so strongly about Tool to the point where they almost worship, I would imagine for the same reason I do. Tool's music and lyrics explosed me to a world of thought that I had never yet been exposed to. The lyrics and music pointed me the way of a deep study of psychology, eastern religions, human nature and darwinism, fundamental religiousity and it's affect on society and individual's mental health, it's endless...sorry for getting off topic, about Lateralus, my favorite Tool song...

This song seems to be about an internal conflict between the hemispheres of the brain. One with logic and reason, 0's and 1's, black and whites, right and wrong, definity and distinct lines, and one with creativity, colors, blurred lines, inspiration, art, and spirituality.

Maynard talks about his personal awakening, and his realization of this necessity for balance between left and right.

The references and the use of the fibonacci sequence is especially interesting. It's no doubt in my mind that "spiralling out" refers the the spirals created by the fibonacci sequence, which was clearly used in the "black and white" section of the song.

I think what maynard discovered was that all this logic, all these numbers(1,1,2,3,5,8,13) just describe something immensely beautiful. The patterns found in nature are what we would describe as beauty. Maynard had first learned only to see the world in a very dry, logical perception. He saw the world in black in white, in equations, in numbers, and only later learned to get in touch with his other half. Witnessing the beauty described by these numbers. And as with a lot of Tool songs, it's at the end where he seems to expose himself and cleanse himself. It's true for everything in our world. Maynard says he wants to FEEL the rhythm. A rhythm is just a mathematical pattern put to sound, but to your creative side, it's something to feel. Something you can relate to, something that invokes emotions...if you let it. Also, I'd say with regard to the "overthinking, overanalyzing separates the body from the mind". It is true that overthinking, and obsessing, and being overly aware of your own conciousness can disconnect your body from your mind, and give you the same out of body experience you get from a lot of drugs, even weed. Not to say that it's a good thing or a bad thing, in this case I'd say it's a bad thing.

And in conclusion, I think Maynard is describing his revelation. His choosing to open up his spiritual side. Drawing outside the lines, feeling emotion, feeling alive, feeling immortal, while still remaining human. 
"...and still be a human."
I think this recognizes the necessity for balance between the two hemispheres. It realizes he can embrace his spiritual side, and recognize how everything is connected(jungian psych), while still remaining human, endowed with reason, and logic.

I'd love to hear responses to my take on this great song...

comment_370: I was told Tool uses many mathematical approaches to their lyrics and music and a certain aspect of this song blew me away.  First, think of the Fibonacci sequence.  The Fibonacci sequence is a pattern of numbers as such: 1,1,2,3,5,8,13...etc.  Each number is added to the preceding number to obtain the number that follows.  In the first lines of Lateralus, this sequence is used.  The use of the pattern is in the syllable sequence as well as pauses.  Between each pause are a number of syllables equal to the number pattern of the Fibonacci.  See:  Black (1) then (1) white are (2) all I see (3) in my in-fan-cy (5) red and yel-low then came to be (8) rea-ching out to me (5) lets me see (3).  As you can see these lines follow an up down pattern of the Fibonacci sequence.  Friggin awesome huh?

Hey there! Im listening to a lot of Tool again as I work, so its fun to see how you all interpret their great lyrics. Real neat website here. 

As for this song, I think that many people have glimpsed some true spiritual insight in this song. Maynard is very clever and makes his words such that they can mean many things to many people. Here is how I see these particular verses.

As I did yesterday with "Third Eye" I come at this from a Hindu philosophical perspective. To me he is describing yet again more aspects of awakening the consciousness upward along the cerebrospinal axis of the human body. As I mentioned before, each ascending chakra has a correlating Aum sound vibration. Also there is a corresponding color. Norse mythology mentions crossing the rainbow Bifrost bridge to Asgaard, home of the gods. This is an analogy for crossing the entire spectrum of colors inside the human animal ascending from red below to purple above, almost coming full perfect circle, striving to go all the way to divine inner consciousness. The microcosmic body of man is mirrored in the macrocosmic world we live in and the universe around us. A hint that there is a master craftsman behind the curtain of reality, pulling them superstrings and making the music of the spheres. 

   Red and yellow is all I see in my infancy. The beginning of the spiritual awakening process. Red is the bottom chakra. Literally. It represents the red hot molten core of the earth and the mud we excrete when we focus at the base of our beings. After that is orange, or water. The more liquid kidney focus, representing the water where it meets the shore. Beyond is yellow, third chakra or fire chakra. This is in the spinal collumn across from the stomach, where everything is burned and broken down. Material ignites and becomes more related to the air element. In the beginning, most people are governed subtly by these lower animalistic driving forces. Eating, ejaculating and excreting waste.

  Green is across from the lungs, or air chakra. In the air, still tied to the earth is where vegetation reaches out. It is still related to the lower forces and begins life as we understand it. Air is above the lower elements.

Beyond is the great blue yonder. The sky, which is actually a reflection of the water below. Up and down we go. The cervix chakra. Where the real contemplating begins. represented by outer space where ether is the element. 

Purple is royal self realization, the crown chakra. All that is beyond our normal perceptions. The Kutastha Chaitanya or "Christ Consciousness' permeating all of creation. When you see that color and hear the ocean combined with thunder and the symphonic sound of everything else, Bingo. (-Ions) Thor is awakening!

  Its easy when contemplating these conditions to think one might be overanalyzing and stretching to find hidden meaning in every thing. Paranoia is often the side dish of genius. But if you truly seek to find the divine within, you have to cross this rainbow bridge and join kermit on the other side in Asgaard. 

  Just my own opinions. I love that everybody can glean what they like from musical poetry of this calibre. To me, the 'spiral' is the construct of infinit space and eternal time combined. We only see pieces of it while experiencing space-time within. Like the swirling arms of a galaxy, the universe is similarly shaped and exists already in perfection stretching to eternity in dimensions beyond our limited 4. 

 I also hear these lyrics slightly differently here:

Reaching out to embrace the random 
Reaching out to embrace what HEAVEN may come

Sounds kooky, eh? Thanks for sharing and listening!~~~Patrick

comment_390:
Okay, I'm gotta break this song down. Every thing I'm about to say may have already been said, but I'm gotta say it all anyway.
"Black then white are all I see in my infancy, 
red then yellow then came to be
reaching out to me, let's me see"
I think that's saying that at first when you're young, before you start thinking about the big questions, all you see is the obvious, only what you can see with your eyes, the black and white. But then later on, you begin to see more, the small details, the big questions, the other hues like red and yellow.
"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
drawn beyond the lines of reason.
Push the envelope. Watch it bend." 
The lines 'as below, so above and beyond' I'm not too sure about, but maybe it's saying every part of him, from below to beyond (or maybe as he always has or as all humanity/life has been trying to do) is imagining outside what's considered normal and he is then telling you to do the same. To think outside the envelope and see what happens.
"Over thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind.
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities and I must
Feed my will to feel my moment drawing way outside the lines."
When you think too much and analyze everything before you actually act upon it is separating what you believe and think in your mind from your actions. And so you're not following your instincts and they're drying up, causing you to miss opportunities that would have come from those actions had you acted upon them. Then he's saying he has to fulfill his need to feel the moment even if it's out of the norm.
"Black then white are, all i see in my infancy.
red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me. 
lets me see
there is so much more and beckons me
to look thru to these infinite possibilities." 
With the addition of the 'there is so much more...' (though it could also be a different statement) it's saying that because he can see those red and yellow hues it's allowing him to see so much more than before, beckoning him to look into them and realize the infinite possibilities that they bring.
"As below, so above and beyond, I imagine
drawn outside the lines of reason.
Push the envelope. Watch it bend.
Over thinking, over analyzing separates the body from the mind.
Withering my intuition leaving opportunities behind."
Same as before.
"Feed my will to feel this moment, urging me to cross the line.
Reaching out to embrace the random. 
Reaching out to embrace whatever may come."
His need to feel the moment is urging him to cross that line of 'normality'. And so he's trying to get to the point where he can act upon his thoughts without 'overthinking, overanalyzing' them.
"embrace my
desire to (2x)
feel the rhythm, to
feel connected,
enough to step aside and, 
weep like a widow, to 
feel inspired, to 
fathom the power, to 
witness the beauty, to 
bathe in the fountain, to
swing on the spiral, to 
swing on the spiral,"
That whole thing I think is just saying that he's embracing his desire to feel connected to the whole of the universe and be able to relate to the feelings of others and gain from them.
"to swing on the spiral of 
our divinity and 
still be a human"
Maybe to explore our god-likeness, meaning our ability to care, love, see all, and be unusual, with others still understanding that even though we're different, we're still human.
"With my feet upon the ground I move myself between the sounds and open wide to suck it in. 
I feel it move across my skin."
He's not crazy (or on crack, as others seem to claim people are on if they're really weird), but rather completely stable and moving between different worlds, different realities, different ways of life and taking everything he sees in and learning from it while feeling the knowledge go through his body. (I can't explain the "move myself between the sounds" very well, that's the best I could do.)
"I'm reaching up and reaching out. I'm reaching for the random or what ever will bewilder me.
what ever will bewilder me."
Pretty much the same as the embracing the random part. He's reaching for the random or anything different, maybe hoping to learn from it.
"And following our will and wind we may just go where no one's been."
And when we follow our instincts and randomness we will find knowledge and possibilities that no one has ever thought of.
"We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been."
We'll continue riding that uncharted spiral to our divinity all the way to the end [of humanity maybe?] and go places and discover things no one has ever before.
"Spiral out. Keep going 4x"
Just keep spiraling out, being different and out of the norm.

So following my interpretation it's really a kind of repetitive song, saying the same message over and over again. But it's an important one so Maynard [and probably the rest of the band, I'm sure] is really trying to get it through to us. 
I've been wondering though if instead of 'move myself between the sounds' it's 'lose myself' and instead of 'open wide to suck it in' it's 'open wide to tuck it in'?....

(wants to see how long her post is)

comment_419:
Hey guys. First of all I'd like to say that this song means a lot to me. I just recently heard about this site which is why I hadn't written on this sooner (I made an account just to do this =)). This is the first time I've done this so please bare with whatever errors or philosophical holes there may be. I'm simply writing what this song means to me lyrically.

 I'm just gonna take this line by line, I see that there's already very similar posts to my ideal, but I think I might add some incite. Of course there are some things I don't understand, but it is Tool.


"Black then white are all I see in my infancy
Red and yellow then came to be, reaching out to me, let's me see"

I saw someone suggest that this may have to do with skin colors, and why that may be true that's not what I'm thinking. This line is dealing with religious leaders or followers (or anyone, religious or not) that deal in extreme absolutes (i.e progressive or angry music is all bad; "No matter what that song means it has an angry melody... can't be good"). From what I've read about Maynard it seems that he justifies       with the idea that they open the mind to new ways of thinking and enhances certain ways of thinking, so that may be specifically what he's talking about. 

Black and white represent absolutes, which is why I think he may be referring to religion. Having come from a religious background myself, I know how pushy some people can be with the ideals they've been molded into. Don't get me wrong, I'm actually an avid Christian, but the Church could definitely be reached out to and wrought out of the mold that older more formal church people have set them into.


 "As below, so above and beyond, I imagine 
Drawn beyond the lines of reason 
Push the envelope, watch it bend"


  This line for me is saying that because I have been very low in life I can imagine the opposite "above and beyond".  My  thoughts have set my standards above the norm that I've been exposed to, this seems strange to others; their envelope is being pushed and all they can do is watch bend until something blows over (bends).

 "Over thinking, over analyzing, separate the body from the mind 
Withering my intuition, missing opportunities..."


This line is saying that over thinking can separate what you would like to do from what you do. If you do this you will miss opportunities that cannot be reachieved, you must not let your instincts (intuition) whither. 

"...and I must 
Feed my will to feel my moment, drawing way outside the lines"

  This refers to a child's coloring book, teachers and day care workers will insist that you draw within the lines because the picture is set and you can't change it. That would be juvenile.


 "There is so much more and beckons me to look through to these infinite possibilities"

  This is reiterating what has been said earlier. There is a calling that goes beyond the status quo most of us have been exposed to. But there are other people and things that call us all to endless looked-over or seemingly grotesque  possibilities.


 "Over thinking, over analyzing, separate the body from the mind 
Withering my intuition, leaving opportunities behind "

This is the same as the first chorus except for 
      "leaving opportunities behind"
which really just strengthens the idea that these opportunities are irretrievable and must not be missed. Life is special; every moment counts.



 "Feed my will to feel this moment 
  Urging me to cross the line
  Reaching out to embrace the random  
 Reaching out to embrace whatever may come"

  A line has been set-- either do what others have or be disowned. I think the writer of this song had looked for some sort of encouragement as he "embraces the random"



 "I embrace my 
Desire to 
I embrace my 
Desire to 
Feel the rhythm, to 
Feel connected 
Enough to step aside and 
Weep like a widow, to 
Feel inspired, to 
Fathom the power, to 
Witness the beauty, to 
Bathe in the fountain, to 
Swing on the spiral, to 
Swing on the spiral, to"


   In this line, like much of the song, the writer has embraced his desire to do what others fear and     . This is not only suggesting the extreme, but doing whatever he feels and not be afraid of what the normal may think of him, but also to step aside when he feels things need to take care of themselves.

To  "Swing on the spiral" is completely a mystery to me, and though I've no idea what it means it doesn't dampen the songs impact on my life.

 "Swing on the spiral of 
Our divinity and 
Still be a human "

 Again, I have no idea what he is talking about interpret as you will.



"With my feet upon the ground I move myself between the sounds 
And open wide to suck it in, I feel it move across my skin 
I'm reachin' up and reachin' out, I'm reachin' for the random or 
Whatever will bewilder me, whatever will bewilder me 
And following our will and wind, we may just go where no one's been 
We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been"


This line is much like the rest of the song, but with a big difference. This is more of a declaration than a statement or suggestion. The writer now knows what he must do and has the support of another party, and they must do whatever they feel called to. This may make your life very erratic, but it is a good way to find your 'calling'.


 "Spiral out 
Keep going 
Spiral out 
Keep going 
Spiral out 
Keep going 
Spiral out! 
Keep going"

The writer is now telling the opposing party to do as he has done and let their lives unwind to find who they really are, and though it may feel uncomfortable it's best to not stop.


Well that's all I got. Hope this answered some questions. Please understand that the above is what this song means to me, you might interpret it differently than I, so feel free to post; spiral out.

comment_422:
well first off this is just my personal opinion on these lyrics and TOOL lyrics in general, and yes i do realise i am being very hypocritical and you will see this as you read on..

"Over thinking, over analyzing, separate the body from the mind "

To me this is the key line of this song, it summarises maynards feeling towards all of his music. Its saying that we, the collective audience and society in general, look to find an answer and meaning in something that does not HAVE to have meaning. I realise im being highly hypocritical with this analysis but i think its something every serious TOOL fan should consider. We are trying to find meaning and truth in lyrics and verse when we should be "separating the body from the mind" or in other words the physical context from the spiritual and intellectual. We shouldnt have to analise everything we do in life, we should take it as it comes and trust our intuition and emotional interpretations. How we initally FEEL about the song (including its musical elements) before we read the lyrics can be much more important the how we interpret the lyrics.

This of course is a much more general statement and is not confined to this song. There are many more themes and messages Maynard is trying to get across to us in Lateralus but i think this is the most important, as it carries across all of TOOLs work, and any subjective art in general.

comment_432:
There are several interpretations to this song. This is my own: 

If you look at a bunch of key words, you will find a LOT of them relate directly to the creation of music. For example, 

"Black and white are all I see in my infancy"
To me, this means a plain, clear slate for creativity. For example, when in the studio, if you look at a sound compressor, or other metered equipment, they are pretty much black and white (plain/no lighting/etc). Some of them are actually black and white in color. Once  they are turned on, "Red and Yellow they came to me". The bars on the amps, compressors and every other metered sound equipment become "red and yellow." 

When he speaks of "so much more that beckons me, to look through to these infinite possibilities"

To me, this means, there is an infinite amount of music arrangements, sounds, and creative factors (in terms of music).

He speaks of "push the envelope, watch it bend". 

An envelope, used in sound terms, means:
The contours that affect the characteristics of a sound (pitch, tone and volume) over time. For example, when a string is plucked, its amplitude is suddenly very loud, but then dies out gradually. This describes the volume envelope of the sound."

When he speaks of "so much more that beckons me, to look through to these infinite possibilities"
Unlimited arrangements and sound manipulation regarding, vocals and other aspects.

"With my feet upon the ground I move myself between the sounds And open wide to suck it in, I feel it move across my skin, I'm reachin' up and reachin' out, I'm reachin' for the random or Whatever will bewilder me, whatever will bewilder me "

IMO, again, related to sound and the way it creates an emotion or inspires artistic creativity. There are infinite  sequential possibilities for sound arrangement. They are intriguing, taking the creator and listener into their own direction. 

"I embrace my
Desire to
I embrace my
Desire to
Feel the rhythm, to
Feel connected
Enough to step aside and
Weep like a widow, to
Feel inspired, to
Fathom the power, to
Witness the beauty, to
Bathe in the fountain, to
Swing on the spiral, to
Swing on the spiral, to"

Weeping, understanding, and bathing in the beauty creation and its connectivity to music as a whole. 

Enjoy!

i think the golden spirals might refer to "The Golden Spiral"

"The Golden Spiral is a mystical shape that is an absolute in both abstract mathematics and chaotic nature. It was first discovered by Phythagoras, a failed Greek messiah and mathematical cult leader in the 5th century B.C.

The spiral is derived via the golden rectangle, a unique rectangle which has the golden ratio. When squared, it leaves a smaller rectangle behind, which has the same golden ratio as the previous rectangle. The squaring can continue indefinitely with the same result. No other rectangle has this trait.


When you connect a curve through the corners of these concentric rectangles, you have formed the golden spiral. The Phythagoreans loved this shape for they found it everywhere in nature: the Nautilus Shell, Ram's horns, milk in coffee, the face of a Sunflower, your fingerprints, our DNA, and the shape of the Milky Way." - pithemovie.com/…

This is the Hermetic principle of correspondence. All seven of the Hermetic principles are used within various mystery schools (Thelema, Theosophy, etc). The one thing all these schools have in common, in relation to the Hermetic principles, is the necessity of the death of the ego in order to transcend and grow spiritually. That's what this whole album, this song especially, seems to be saying.

comment_457:
Personally i've got a thing for sound... sound is everywhere and can depict anything, from a mad guitar riff, to drums pounding to someones voice. 

This song is awesome in all regards of lyrical content ambuguity and most importantly sound. I think the songs full power and message are developed in the first couple of minutes, Maynard introduces the thoughts of two different parts needing to come together, namely the soul/mind (whichever u prefer) and body. But the full message of the song is finally deliverd to you in steps from the line "I embrace my...". 

If you notice as in many Tool songs, they start off pretty gentle or more controlled but by the end are powerfull enough to leave you gasping for breath, BUT with this song it has two build ups... the first is the introduction which is summed up by the riff after the line "...leaving opportunities behind." Which then leads to, Maynard delivering his conclusion in the second build up which is now what i'm gonna explain (sorry if ur bored)

To get the full meaning of the ending you have to do just what Maynard is telling, put two parts together, the spiritual and physical and that to me is defined by his lyrics and the powerful sounds brought into the song by the all the instruments as "I embrace my desire to feel the rythm, to feel connected... to feel inspired, to fathom the power..." all this lies in a complete BALANCED symbiosis of both spirit and mind through sound (or whatever releases you) is how to acheive the higher state of being introduced to us in the beginning and hinted at as a form of dis-embodiment "With my feet upon the ground I move myself between the sounds..."

To fully explore my interpretation of this song try this: listen to the song through headphones and the point i said the "ending" comes turn the volume up (most of us do this anyway) and listen to the perfect blending of Maynards voice to all the instruments from the quiet "I embrace my..." to the thunderous "Spiral out... keep going" and if you're lying down the better, because you will feel your spirit soar.

Thanks for taking the time, Tool forever :)

comment_463:
I hear many Nietzschian (I don't think thats a word) themes when I listen to this song. Nietzsche believed in eternal recurrence, the idea that we will live this life an infinite number of times over and nothing will change. we are just along for the ride in life, and instead of being bummed by this man is supposed to 'embrace' his situation and 'will' his life. This connects with the parts of the song about embracing the random and feeding the will to feel the moment.

Also, Nietzsche, like other existential philosophers, was critical of the philosophers of the time. He thought that living solely by reason and not by feeling was wrong ( check dionysus vs. apollo and "Notes from Underground by Doestoyevsky). This relates to the outside of reason push the envelope part. 

So this interpretation doesn't pertain to every line or anything, but hopefully it may add some to the discussion. I recommend everyone read a little of the very misunderstood Nietzsche, he is quite interesting.
comment_464:
In order to properly understand songs by tool you need to brush up on Jungian philosophy, Bob Frissell. If you do these things you will better understand the symbolism in the songs. Tool is as a band, is exactly what it is in the dictionary. A tool. An instrument used to accomplish another task. The main concepts in Tools work is the evolution of the mind by overcoming your shadow. Your shadow being the thoughts and feelings that your unconscious harbors that prohibit you from being one with your self. Aenima and Lateralus are both about the process of overcoming this shadow. Or so to speak, stepping aside (laterally) and becoming one with your shadow (which is a very difficult process). And to become one with your shadow completes your Merkaba which is the completion of entering the third dimension of consciousness, or to reach the 48 chromosone, or to open your third eye. The key to discovering your shadow and to become one with it is to discover your inner most buried thoughts about certain subject matter, to understand it, and then to evolve. Aenima is two words combined into one. Anima is the soul, and enema is the flushing out of your system by means of washing (through the anus). Combine the two, Cleansing of the soul. Hence why the song enema is spelled differently than the album. "Mom please flush it all away...Learn to swim" Flushing of the little meaningless things that consume our life, and on to the new self. Becoming one with your shadow. If you were to look at the song Lateralus as a summary of the journey one takes to reach the third consciousness. 
Black and white are all i see, then red and yellow came to me reaching out to me lets me see. (realizing the beginning of the evolution of the mind gives him a glimpse of a better place..and he wants it)
As below, so above and beyond, I imagine Drawn beyond the lines of reason Push the envelope, watch it bend (No words can describe this new perspective he now takes) Over thinking and over analyzing (getting comfortable enough with oneself to acknowledge his shadow separates the external bullshit from the internal) Withering intuition missing opportunities...urging me to cross the line. (Knowing he is going to leave everything safe behind but he has to step through now that he been given a glimpse of what may be. More and more does he realize that he needs to cross that line and venture on to this new level of consciousness)   I embrace my desire to....Fathom the power and witness the beauty ( Now willing to step aside and confront his inner most demons, in order to exceed beyond what was eventually holding him back from reaching new undiscovered enlightenment) Swing on the spiral and still be human ( swing on the spiral upwards to our new achieved enlightenment and still be  human, just with a new consciousness) 
With my feet upon the ground I move myself between the sounds
And open wide to suck it in, I feel it move across my skin
I'm reachin' up and reachin' out, I'm reachin' for the random or
Whatever will bewilder me, whatever will bewilder me
And following our will and wind, we may just go where no one's been
We'll ride the spiral to the end and may just go where no one's been 

The new stage of enlightenment is now complete

Yep, it goes on like this in the whole song... I'll read all 19 pages later, but now I'm quite in a hurry, so I'll just state what the Fibonacci-sequence represents imo:
The Fibonacci can be interpreted as an outgoing spiral, never ending, and that's what this song is pretty much about: Keep developing your thoughts and never stop at any point of thinking, because you can still improve your view on the situation. Being open minded for "new" things, thinking outside of the box so you can reach a "higher" level of conscience.
The very first 2 sentences can be seen in this way as well: His way of judging the situation develops from a "black and white"-view and gets new aspects.

I think it's a very spiritual song, both in lyrics and the instrumental structure and still one of my favorites of this band. But I wouldn't call this my #1 song, because my hearth would bleed if I had to choose a very favorite. The albums themselves are masterworks. :)

comment_472:
I don't know if any of you are familiar with the theory of "Alchemy" which was disproven when common Physics was discovered. In the whole CD lateralus, Maynard takes text from the old Alchemy theories such as the quote "As be low so above and beyond I imagine" This is taken directly from Alchemic quotes. The reason this is so important is becuase with new discoveries of Quantum Physics, Alchemy is now proven possible (changing lead into gold). The whole theory of Alchemy is based upon the possibility of bending reality. I just finished reading a book called "The Tao of Physics" which is the parallels of Quantum physics with Eastern mysticism (Zen, Tao, ext..) To be quite honest, how similiar they are in theory is scary. This song takes the two and ties them together in a way. In lyric it reminds me of Zen, but in theory it reminds me of Quantum Physics with a little Alchemy. All three are very similiar.

Note in The Grudge he uses (transmute these leaden anchors into gold)
and in nearly all of Schism I find traces of the theory (I know the peices fit 'cause I watched them fall away). Reminds me of how Alchemists use to use different concoctions to apply to lead or other elements and watch them smolder or melt away, them beleiving if they can melt them away they can put them back together again.
In a way the whole CD is one entire element, just seperated by songs.

comment_479:
What I got out of this is so much different than anyone else, but that's one of the many things I love about Tool. I got the idea that he was saying to all of his fans that his music isn't as ddep as we try to make it seem. Black & White at infancy could mean that when he was just starting out, his lyrics were black & white, nothing more. And as he and his band grew to become what they were today, yellow & red became apparent, through the eyes of his fans. 

To help back my point, he says "Over thinking, over analyzing, separate the body from the mind".... "Drawn beyond the lines of reason 
Push the envelope, watch it bend"
--- I think he is saying that when he releases songs, he watches his fans take his simple meanings and "push the envelope"; stretch his words to fit whatever they so choose.

Well that's my interpretation of it anyway, but then again; maybe I'm just over analyzing it????
